events.title: Dr. Livesey's Intervention and Diagnosis
characters: Captain (Billy Bones, also referred to as Billy Bones/Mr. Bones)
detailed_summary: Jim and his mother anxiously appealed to Dr. Livesey, asking for guidance and inquiring about the location of the captain's supposed wound.
Dr. Livesey summarily dismissed the notion of a wound, asserting that the captain had suffered a stroke, an event he had previously warned the captain about.
He directed Mrs. Hawkins to return to her husband and, if feasible, to avoid alarming him with details of the incident.
Dr. Livesey expressed his resolve to attempt to save the captain's life, despite deeming it "trebly worthless," and requested Jim to bring him a basin.
Upon Jim's return with the basin, he found that Dr. Livesey had already cut open the captain's sleeve, exposing a brawny and muscular arm adorned with several tattoos.
Among the tattoos were inscriptions such as "Here’s luck," "A fair wind," and "Billy Bones his fancy," all legibly and skillfully inked on the forearm.
Higher up, near the shoulder, was a graphic illustration of a gallows with a figure hanging from it, which the narrator thought was rendered with considerable artistic flair.
Dr. Livesey touched the gallows tattoo with his finger and remarked that it was "Prophetic."
Addressing the still-unconscious captain as "Master Billy Bones," the doctor announced his intention to examine the captain's blood and casually asked Jim if he was squeamish about the sight of it.
Jim affirmed that he was not afraid of blood.
Dr. Livesey then instructed Jim to hold the basin, took out his lancet, and proceeded to open a vein on the captain's arm.
A substantial quantity of blood was drawn before the captain finally regained consciousness and looked about him with a hazy, unfocused gaze.

He initially recognized Dr. Livesey, his expression clearly one of displeasure; his gaze then shifted to Jim, and he appeared somewhat reassured. However, his complexion abruptly changed, and he made an effort to sit up, urgently asking about the whereabouts of Black Dog.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: “Oh, doctor,” we cried, “what shall we do? Where is he wounded?”
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: First he recognized the doctor with an unmistakable frown; then his glance fell upon me, and he looked relieved. But suddenly his colour changed, and he tried to raise himself, crying, “Where’s Black Dog?”

events.text_segment:
“Oh, doctor,” we cried, “what shall we do? Where is he wounded?”
“Wounded? A fiddle-stick’s end!” said the doctor. “No more wounded than you or I. The man has had a stroke, as I warned him. Now, Mrs. Hawkins, just you run upstairs to your husband and tell him, if possible, nothing about it. For my part, I must do my best to save this fellow’s trebly worthless life; Jim, you get me a basin.”
When I got back with the basin, the doctor had already ripped up the captain’s sleeve and exposed his great sinewy arm. It was tattooed in several places. “Here’s luck,” “A fair wind,” and “Billy Bones his fancy,” were very neatly and clearly executed on the forearm; and up near the shoulder there was a sketch of a gallows and a man hanging from it—done, as I thought, with great spirit.
“Prophetic,” said the doctor, touching this picture with his finger. “And now, Master Billy Bones, if that be your name, we’ll have a look at the colour of your blood. Jim,” he said, “are you afraid of blood?”
“No, sir,” said I.
“Well, then,” said he, “you hold the basin”; and with that he took his lancet and opened a vein.
A great deal of blood was taken before the captain opened his eyes and looked mistily about him. First he recognized the doctor with an unmistakable frown; then his glance fell upon me, and he looked relieved. But suddenly his colour changed, and he tried to raise himself, crying, “Where’s Black Dog?”

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction:
"Oh, doctor," we cried, "what shall we do? Where is he wounded?"

"Wounded!" said the doctor, "he's had a stroke, and a very bad one. I told him so, and he wouldn't listen."

"A stroke!" cried my mother, turning pale.

"Yes," said the doctor, "and a stroke is no joke. You'd better go back to your husband, Mrs. Hawkins, and if you can, keep him from being alarmed."

"But what shall we do for him?"

"I'll do what I can," said the doctor, "though I fear it's trebly worthless. Jim, bring me a basin."

I ran and brought the basin, and when I returned, the doctor had already cut open the captain's sleeve, revealing a strong, muscular arm, tattooed with several marks.

"Here’s luck," "A fair wind," and "Billy Bones his fancy," were all plainly and neatly marked on the forearm.

Higher up, near the shoulder, was a gallows with a figure hanging from it, drawn with a curious skill.

The doctor touched the gallows with his finger and said, "Prophetic."

"Master Billy Bones," said the doctor, "I must take a look at your blood. Jim, are you squeamish?"

"No, sir," I answered.

"Then hold the basin," said the doctor, drawing his lancet and opening a vein in the captain's arm.

A good deal of blood flowed before the captain opened his eyes and looked about him with a dull, uncertain gaze.

He recognized the doctor first, and his face showed displeasure; then he looked at me, and seemed somewhat reassured. Suddenly his color changed, and he tried to sit up, asking anxiously, "Where's Black Dog?"

“Oh, doctor,” we cried, “what shall we do? Where is he wounded?”

Dr. Livesey looked grave but composed. “He’s been shot in the leg, but the bullet hasn’t done much damage. The main danger is infection, so we must act quickly and keep him clean.”

Jim and I exchanged worried glances. The pirate, our erstwhile enemy, now lay helpless before us, and it was our duty to save him.

“Bring some clean cloths and water,” the doctor ordered. “We’ll have to dress the wound and keep him under close watch.”

As we worked, the pirate’s breathing grew steadier, and a faint color returned to his cheeks. “Thank you,” he muttered hoarsely. “I owe you my life.”

Dr. Livesey nodded. “You’ll need to rest and stay quiet. No more fighting for now.”

The days that followed were tense. We guarded the ship against any further attacks, while tending to the wounded man. Slowly, he regained strength, and with it, a measure of trust.

One evening, as the sun dipped below the horizon, he spoke. “I’m called Long John Silver,” he said. “I’ve been a pirate all my life, but perhaps there’s a better way.”

His words surprised us, but in that moment, we saw not a villain, but a man seeking redemption. The adventure on Treasure Island had changed us all, teaching lessons of courage, loyalty, and the hope for a new beginning.

events.title: Dr. Livesey's Dire Warning to the Captain
detailed_summary: Dr. Livesey informed the captain that Black Dog was not present, adding a metaphorical comment about the burdens the captain carried.
He firmly reiterated that the captain's condition was due to excessive rum consumption leading to a stroke, precisely as he had forewarned.
The doctor stated that he had just, with considerable reluctance, managed to save the captain from death.
When Dr. Livesey addressed him as "Mr. Bones," the captain interrupted to say that was not his name.

Dr. Livesey showed little concern for the captain's actual name, explaining he used "Bones" as it was the name of a buccaneer he knew and it served for brevity. He then delivered a critical warning: while a single glass of rum might not be fatal, continued indulgence would inevitably lead to more consumption and ultimately to his death.
He implored the captain to comprehend the seriousness of his condition and to make a genuine effort towards recovery.
Dr. Livesey then offered, for this occasion only, to assist the captain in getting to his bed.
With significant difficulty, Jim and Dr. Livesey together hoisted the captain upstairs and helped him onto his bed, where his head lolled back on the pillow as if he were on the verge of fainting.
As a final, solemn pronouncement, Dr. Livesey declared that his conscience was clear: for the captain, any association with rum signified death.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: “There is no Black Dog here,” said the doctor, “except what you have on your own back.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: “Now, mind you,” said the doctor, “I clear my conscience—the name of rum for you is death.”

events.text_segment:
“There is no Black Dog here,” said the doctor, “except what you have on your own back. You have been drinking rum; you have had a stroke, precisely as I told you; and I have just, very much against my own will, dragged you headforemost out of the grave. Now, Mr. Bones—”
“That’s not my name,” he interrupted.
“Much I care,” returned the doctor. “It’s the name of a buccaneer of my acquaintance; and I call you by it for the sake of shortness, and what I have to say to you is this; one glass of rum won’t kill you, but if you take one you’ll take another and another, and I stake my wig if you don’t break off short, you’ll die—do you understand that?—die, and go to your own place, like the man in the Bible. Come, now, make an effort. I’ll help you to your bed for once.”
Between us, with much trouble, we managed to hoist him upstairs, and laid him on his bed, where his head fell back on the pillow as if he were almost fainting.
“Now, mind you,” said the doctor, “I clear my conscience—the name of rum for you is death.”

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction:
"There is no Black Dog here," said the doctor, "except what you have on your own back."

"I tell you, doctor," said the captain, "that Black Dog was here but now he's gone."

"I don't doubt it," said Dr. Livesey, "but the Black Dog you have to fear is the one inside you."

"I know what I have," said the captain, "and I know what I have not."

"Mr. Bones," said the doctor, "I have just saved your life, though I did it with a heavy heart."

"Mr. Bones?" interrupted the captain. "That's not my name."

"I know," said the doctor, "but I call you Bones because it suits you, and because it is the name of a buccaneer I once knew. But listen to me: one glass of rum may not kill you, but it will lead to another, and another, until it kills you for sure."

"You must understand, captain," said Dr. Livesey, "that your condition is the result of too much rum, and that you must make a real effort to recover."

"For this once," he added, "I will help you to your bed."

With great difficulty, Jim and the doctor lifted the captain upstairs and laid him on his bed. His head lolled back on the pillow as if he were about to faint.

"My conscience is clear," said Dr. Livesey solemnly. "For you, captain, rum means death."

events.title: The Doctor's Prognosis and Advice to Jim
detailed_summary: After delivering his warning to the captain, Dr. Livesey departed to attend to Jim's father, taking Jim along by the arm.
Once they had closed the door behind them, the doctor confided in Jim that the bloodletting performed on the captain was primarily intended to keep him sedated for a period.

He advised that the captain should ideally remain confined to his bed for approximately a week, suggesting this would be the most beneficial course of action for both the captain's health and the Hawkins family's peace.
However, Dr. Livesey concluded with a grim prognosis, stating that if the captain were to suffer another stroke, it would unquestionably be fatal.

events.title: The Captain's Desperate Plea for Rum and Ominous Warnings
detailed_summary: Jim visits the captain, finding him physically diminished yet mentally agitated.
The captain implores Jim for rum, dismissing the doctor's advice and recounting how rum has been his sustenance in harsh conditions, asserting Jim is his only reliable associate.
He expresses intense fear of 'the horrors,' claiming to have hallucinated the ghost of old Flint, and his desperation for alcohol escalates.
The captain offers Jim a gold guinea as payment for a noggin of rum.

Concerned for his ailing father's need for tranquility and somewhat insulted by the bribe, Jim agrees to provide only a single glass of rum, emphasizing that his main concern is the debt owed to his father.
After consuming the rum with avidity, the captain inquires about the length of his doctor-ordered confinement.

Learning he must stay in bed for at least a week, he reacts with alarm, fearing his adversaries will deliver the 'black spot' to him within that time, denouncing their unseamanlike tactics and vowing to outmaneuver them.

He makes a strenuous effort to get out of bed, supported by Jim, but his physical frailty is a stark contrast to his defiant words, and he soon collapses back, muttering that the doctor's treatment has enfeebled him.
He then questions Jim about the 'seafaring man' (Black Dog) encountered earlier, labeling him a dangerous individual acting under the influence of even more malevolent figures.

The captain instructs Jim that if he cannot escape and is given the 'black spot,' or if Black Dog or a one-legged seaman reappears, Jim must immediately summon the doctor and local magistrates to secure his sea-chest, which contains the key to Flint's treasure, a secret known only to him.
He clarifies that the 'black spot' serves as a formal summons and pledges to share the rewards equally with Jim if he remains vigilant.
His voice fades, and after reluctantly taking his medicine, he succumbs to a profound, coma-like slumber.

events.text_segment:
About noon I stopped at the captain’s door with some cooling drinks and medicines. He was lying very much as we had left him, only a little higher, and he seemed both weak and excited.
“Jim,” he said, “you’re the only one here that’s worth anything, and you know I’ve been always good to you. Never a month but I’ve given you a silver fourpenny for yourself. And now you see, mate, I’m pretty low, and deserted by all; and Jim, you’ll bring me one noggin of rum, now, won’t you, matey?”
“The doctor—” I began.
But he broke in cursing the doctor, in a feeble voice but heartily. “Doctors is all swabs,” he said; “and that doctor there, why, what do he know about seafaring men? I been in places hot as pitch, and mates dropping round with Yellow Jack, and the blessed land a-heaving like the sea with earthquakes—what to the doctor know of lands like that?—and I lived on rum, I tell you. It’s been meat and drink, and man and wife, to me; and if I’m not to have my rum now I’m a poor old hulk on a lee shore, my blood’ll be on you, Jim, and that doctor swab”; and he ran on again for a while with curses. “Look, Jim, how my fingers fidges,” he continued in the pleading tone. “I can’t keep ’em still, not I. I haven’t had a drop this blessed day. That doctor’s a fool, I tell you. If I don’t have a dram o’ rum, Jim, I’ll have the horrors; I seen some on ’em already. I seen old Flint in the corner there, behind you; as plain as print, I seen him; and if I get the horrors, I’m a man that has lived rough, and I’ll raise Cain. Your doctor hisself said one glass wouldn’t hurt me. I’ll give you a golden guinea for a noggin, Jim.”
He was growing more and more excited, and this alarmed me for my father, who was very low that day and needed quiet; besides, I was reassured by the doctor’s words, now quoted to me, and rather offended by the offer of a bribe.
“I want none of your money,” said I, “but what you owe my father. I’ll get you one glass, and no more.”
When I brought it to him, he seized it greedily and drank it out.
“Aye, aye,” said he, “that’s some better, sure enough. And now, matey, did that doctor say how long I was to lie here in this old berth?”
“A week at least,” said I.
“Thunder!” he cried. “A week! I can’t do that; they’d have the black spot on me by then. The lubbers is going about to get the wind of me this blessed moment; lubbers as couldn’t keep what they got, and want to nail what is another’s. Is that seamanly behaviour, now, I want to know? But I’m a saving soul. I never wasted good money of mine, nor lost it neither; and I’ll trick ’em again. I’m not afraid on ’em. I’ll shake out another reef, matey, and daddle ’em again.”
As he was thus speaking, he had risen from bed with great difficulty, holding to my shoulder with a grip that almost made me cry out, and moving his legs like so much dead weight. His words, spirited as they were in meaning, contrasted sadly with the weakness of the voice in which they were uttered. He paused when he had got into a sitting position on the edge.
“That doctor’s done me,” he murmured. “My ears is singing. Lay me back.”
Before I could do much to help him he had fallen back again to his former place, where he lay for a while silent.
“Jim,” he said at length, “you saw that seafaring man today?”
“Black Dog?” I asked.
“Ah! Black Dog,” says he. “He’s a bad ’un; but there’s worse that put him on. Now, if I can’t get away nohow, and they tip me the black spot, mind you, it’s my old sea-chest they’re after; you get on a horse—you can, can’t you? Well, then, you get on a horse, and go to—well, yes, I will!—to that eternal doctor swab, and tell him to pipe all hands—magistrates and sich—and he’ll lay ’em aboard at the Admiral Benbow—all old Flint’s crew, man and boy, all on ’em that’s left. I was first mate, I was, old Flint’s first mate, and I’m the on’y one as knows the place. He gave it me at Savannah, when he lay a-dying, like as if I was to now, you see. But you won’t peach unless they get the black spot on me, or unless you see that Black Dog again or a seafaring man with one leg, Jim—him above all.”
“But what is the black spot, captain?” I asked.
“That’s a summons, mate. I’ll tell you if they get that. But you keep your weather-eye open, Jim, and I’ll share with you equals, upon my honour.”
He wandered a little longer, his voice growing weaker; but soon after I had given him his medicine, which he took like a child, with the remark, “If ever a seaman wanted drugs, it’s me,” he fell at last into a heavy, swoon-like sleep, in which I left him.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
About noon I stopped at the captain’s door with some cooling drinks and medicines. The cabin was dimly lit, the heavy curtains drawn against the glaring sun. Inside, Captain Smollett lay on his bunk, his face pale but his eyes sharp and alert. He motioned me closer and took the medicine with a grateful nod.

"Thank you, Jim," he said in a low voice. "I’m afraid this fever has me in its grip, but I’ll be all right. We must keep our wits about us."

I nodded, feeling a surge of responsibility. The captain’s illness was a blow to our small band, but I knew we had to stand firm. The treasure was close, and the dangers were mounting.

As I left the cabin, I heard voices from the deck. I hurried up the companionway and found the crew gathered around Long John Silver, who was speaking with a persuasive air. His one leg rested on a barrel, and his parrot squawked loudly from his shoulder.

"Now, mates," Silver was saying, "we’ve come a long way, and the treasure’s within our grasp. But we must be cautious. The captain and his loyal men are on edge, and any misstep could cost us dearly."

Some of the men nodded, their faces hard and determined. Others looked uneasy, glancing at the officers who stood nearby, their hands resting on their cutlasses.

I felt a chill run down my spine. The tension was palpable, and I knew that the coming days would test our courage and loyalty like never before.

Later that afternoon, I found myself alone on the quarterdeck, gazing out at the shimmering sea. The island loomed ahead, a dark silhouette against the setting sun. I thought of my father’s map, the promise of gold and adventure, and the perils that awaited us.

Suddenly, a shadow fell across me. I turned to see Israel Hands, the ship’s coxswain, his face grim and unreadable.

"Jim," he said quietly, "there’s talk among the men. Some are restless, others ready to strike. You’d do well to keep your eyes open."

I swallowed hard, realizing that the line between friend and foe was thinner than I had imagined. Trust was a precious commodity, and betrayal lurked in every corner.

That night, as the ship rocked gently on the waves, I lay awake, listening to the creaking timbers and the distant cries of seabirds. The adventure I had dreamed of was unfolding before me, but it was a dangerous game, and the stakes were higher than I had ever known.

In the days that followed, the island became our battleground. The loyal crew, led by Captain Smollett and the brave Dr. Livesey, fortified our position, while Silver and his band of pirates plotted their moves with cunning and guile.

I found myself caught between two worlds, a boy thrust into the heart of a deadly struggle. But I was determined to see it through, to honor my father’s legacy and to claim the treasure that had drawn us all to this remote and treacherous place.

The story of Treasure Island was far from over, and I knew that the coming chapters would be written in courage, sacrifice, and the unyielding spirit of adventure.

events.title: A Father's Death and the Captain's Troubled Decline
detailed_summary: Jim contemplates informing the doctor about the captain's alarming confessions, partly out of fear that the captain might regret his candor and harm him.
However, this plan is abruptly derailed by the sudden death of Jim's father that same evening, an event that eclipses all other worries.
The family's profound sorrow, coupled with the demands of funeral arrangements and managing the inn, fully occupies Jim, leaving him little time to dwell on the captain or his fears.

The captain manages to come downstairs the next morning, consuming little food but, Jim suspects, more than his usual share of rum, which he helps himself to from the bar with a menacing attitude that deters anyone from challenging him.
The night before the funeral, the captain is exceptionally drunk, his boisterous singing of his coarse sea-shanty deeply inappropriate in the grieving household.
Despite his evident weakness, the family and staff remain terrified of him; meanwhile, the doctor has been called away to a distant case and does not return after Jim's father's passing.

Jim observes that the captain's physical state seems to deteriorate rather than improve, as he struggles to navigate stairs and move about, often relying on walls for support and breathing laboriously.
The captain no longer addresses Jim directly, appearing to have forgotten their earlier confidential exchange.

His temperament becomes increasingly volatile and, considering his physical debility, more violent than ever; he develops an unsettling habit of drawing his cutlass and placing it on the table before him when intoxicated.

Despite these outbursts, he seems more withdrawn into his own thoughts and somewhat disoriented, once astonishing everyone by singing a gentle, old-fashioned country love song, likely learned before his seafaring life.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: What I should have done had all gone well I do not know.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Once, for instance, to our extreme wonder, he piped up to a different air, a kind of country love-song that he must have learned in his youth before he had begun to follow the sea.

events.text_segment:
What I should have done had all gone well I do not know. Probably I should have told the whole story to the doctor, for I was in mortal fear lest the captain should repent of his confessions and make an end of me. But as things fell out, my poor father died quite suddenly that evening, which put all other matters on one side. Our natural distress, the visits of the neighbours, the arranging of the funeral, and all the work of the inn to be carried on in the meanwhile kept me so busy that I had scarcely time to think of the captain, far less to be afraid of him.
He got downstairs next morning, to be sure, and had his meals as usual, though he ate little and had more, I am afraid, than his usual supply of rum, for he helped himself out of the bar, scowling and blowing through his nose, and no one dared to cross him. On the night before the funeral he was as drunk as ever; and it was shocking, in that house of mourning, to hear him singing away at his ugly old sea-song; but weak as he was, we were all in the fear of death for him, and the doctor was suddenly taken up with a case many miles away and was never near the house after my father’s death. I have said the captain was weak, and indeed he seemed rather to grow weaker than regain his strength. He clambered up and down stairs, and went from the parlour to the bar and back again, and sometimes put his nose out of doors to smell the sea, holding on to the walls as he went for support and breathing hard and fast like a man on a steep mountain. He never particularly addressed me, and it is my belief he had as good as forgotten his confidences; but his temper was more flighty, and allowing for his bodily weakness, more violent than ever. He had an alarming way now when he was drunk of drawing his cutlass and laying it bare before him on the table. But with all that, he minded people less and seemed shut up in his own thoughts and rather wandering. Once, for instance, to our extreme wonder, he piped up to a different air, a kind of country love-song that he must have learned in his youth before he had begun to follow the sea.

What I should have done had all gone well I do not know. But as it was, the adventure that unfolded was beyond anything I had ever imagined. It began with a mysterious map, a relic of a bygone era, leading to the fabled Treasure Island. The promise of untold riches and the thrill of the unknown beckoned me, and I found myself drawn into a world of pirates, danger, and intrigue.

The journey was perilous from the start. We set sail aboard the Hispaniola, a sturdy ship commanded by the seasoned Captain Smollett. Among the crew were men whose intentions were as murky as the depths of the sea. The cook, Long John Silver, was a man of charm and cunning, his wooden leg a testament to a life lived on the edge. Little did I know that he harbored secrets that would soon come to light.

As we neared the island, tensions aboard the ship grew. Whispers of mutiny filled the air, and alliances shifted like the tides. The map, our guide to the treasure, became both a beacon of hope and a source of conflict. The island itself was a place of mystery, with dense forests, hidden coves, and the remnants of past adventures etched into its landscape.

Upon landing, the true test began. We faced not only the elements but also the treachery of those who sought the treasure for themselves. Battles were fought in the shadows, and trust was a scarce commodity. Through it all, I learned the value of courage, loyalty, and the resilience of the human spirit.

The treasure, when finally uncovered, was more than just gold and jewels. It was a symbol of the journey, the trials endured, and the friendships forged in the crucible of adversity. Though the path was fraught with danger, the experience left an indelible mark on my soul.

Looking back, I realize that the true treasure was not the riches we sought but the adventure itself. It taught me lessons that no amount of gold could buy and shaped the man I would become. Had all gone well, perhaps I would have taken a different path, but fate had other plans, and I am grateful for the story that unfolded.

events.title: The Ominous Arrival of a Blind Visitor
detailed_summary: Time progresses until the afternoon following the funeral, a day marked by bitter cold, fog, and frost. Jim is standing at the inn's entrance, immersed in sorrowful reflections about his father.
He notices a figure slowly making its way towards the inn along the road.
The approaching individual is evidently blind, navigating with a tapping stick and wearing a prominent green shade that covers his eyes and nose.

He is stooped, appearing aged or infirm, and is clad in a voluminous, ancient, and ragged sea-cloak equipped with a hood, which contributes to an overall impression of deformity and dread, making him the most frightening figure Jim has ever encountered.

The blind man halts a short distance from the inn and, employing an unusual, lilting tone, addresses the empty air before him, asking if a compassionate person might inform him of his current location, adding that he lost his sight in noble service to England.
Jim responds, telling him he is at the 'Admiral Benbow, Black Hill Cove.'
The blind man, acknowledging Jim's youthful voice, requests that Jim offer his hand and guide him into the inn.

events.text_segment:
So things passed until, the day after the funeral, and about three o’clock of a bitter, foggy, frosty afternoon, I was standing at the door for a moment, full of sad thoughts about my father, when I saw someone drawing slowly near along the road. He was plainly blind, for he tapped before him with a stick and wore a great green shade over his eyes and nose; and he was hunched, as if with age or weakness, and wore a huge old tattered sea-cloak with a hood that made him appear positively deformed. I never saw in my life a more dreadful-looking figure. He stopped a little from the inn, and raising his voice in an odd sing-song, addressed the air in front of him, “Will any kind friend inform a poor blind man, who has lost the precious sight of his eyes in the gracious defence of his native country, England—and God bless King George!—where or in what part of this country he may now be?”
“You are at the Admiral Benbow, Black Hill Cove, my good man,” said I.
“I hear a voice,” said he, “a young voice. Will you give me your hand, my kind young friend, and lead me in?”

LLM_completions.prefix-probing: The figure was that of an old seaman, tall and gaunt, with a weather-beaten face and a long gray beard. He wore a red waistcoat and a tarpaulin hat, and carried a heavy sea-chest on his back. As he came nearer, I recognized him as the man who had been a friend of my father's, and who had once sailed with him on the Spanish Main. He stopped at the gate, and looking at me with a keen, searching eye, he said, "Is this the house of the late Captain Flint?" I nodded, and he went on, "I am a friend of his, and I have come to see you about a matter of great importance." I invited him in, and we sat down by the fire, while he told me strange tales of buried treasure and secret maps, which set my heart beating with excitement and fear.

events.title: The Blind Man Delivers the Black Spot
detailed_summary: Jim extends his hand, which the blind man, despite his soft-spoken demeanor, seizes with an iron grip that alarms Jim.
The blind man then yanks Jim towards him and curtly orders Jim to take him to the captain.

Jim hesitates, expressing concern for the blind man's own safety, alluding to the captain's unstable condition and his habit of keeping a drawn cutlass, but the blind man contemptuously dismisses this and physically compels Jim by painfully twisting his arm, threatening to break it.
The sheer cruelty, coldness, and ugliness in the blind man's voice intimidate Jim more profoundly than the physical pain, leading to his immediate compliance.
Jim guides the blind man, who maintains a tight grip and leans heavily on him, into the inn and towards the parlor where the captain is sitting in a rum-induced stupor.

As they approach, the blind man commands Jim to announce his arrival by shouting, 'Here's a friend for you, Bill,' reinforcing the order with another painful twitch that nearly makes Jim faint from terror, overriding his fear of the captain.
With a trembling voice, Jim opens the parlor door and utters the prescribed words.

The captain looks up, and the sight of the blind visitor instantly dispels his drunkenness, leaving him staring with an expression not of fear, but of profound, deathly illness; he attempts to stand but appears too weak.
The blind man orders Bill to remain seated, asserting he can detect any movement despite his blindness, then directs Jim to take the captain's left hand and present it to his own right hand.
Both Jim and the captain obey precisely; Jim observes the blind man transfer a small object from the hand holding his stick into the captain's palm, which the captain immediately closes upon it.

Declaring his 'business' concluded, the blind man abruptly releases Jim and, with astonishing speed and agility, darts out of the parlor and onto the road, his tapping stick quickly fading into the distance as Jim remains frozen in place.

events.text_segment:
I held out my hand, and the horrible, soft-spoken, eyeless creature gripped it in a moment like a vise. I was so much startled that I struggled to withdraw, but the blind man pulled me close up to him with a single action of his arm.
“Now, boy,” he said, “take me in to the captain.”
“Sir,” said I, “upon my word I dare not.”
“Oh,” he sneered, “that’s it! Take me in straight or I’ll break your arm.”
And he gave it, as he spoke, a wrench that made me cry out.
“Sir,” said I, “it is for yourself I mean. The captain is not what he used to be. He sits with a drawn cutlass. Another gentleman—”
“Come, now, march,” interrupted he; and I never heard a voice so cruel, and cold, and ugly as that blind man’s. It cowed me more than the pain, and I began to obey him at once, walking straight in at the door and towards the parlour, where our sick old buccaneer was sitting, dazed with rum. The blind man clung close to me, holding me in one iron fist and leaning almost more of his weight on me than I could carry. “Lead me straight up to him, and when I’m in view, cry out, ‘Here’s a friend for you, Bill.’ If you don’t, I’ll do this,” and with that he gave me a twitch that I thought would have made me faint. Between this and that, I was so utterly terrified of the blind beggar that I forgot my terror of the captain, and as I opened the parlour door, cried out the words he had ordered in a trembling voice.
The poor captain raised his eyes, and at one look the rum went out of him and left him staring sober. The expression of his face was not so much of terror as of mortal sickness. He made a movement to rise, but I do not believe he had enough force left in his body.
“Now, Bill, sit where you are,” said the beggar. “If I can’t see, I can hear a finger stirring. Business is business. Hold out your left hand. Boy, take his left hand by the wrist and bring it near to my right.”
We both obeyed him to the letter, and I saw him pass something from the hollow of the hand that held his stick into the palm of the captain’s, which closed upon it instantly.
“And now that’s done,” said the blind man; and at the words he suddenly left hold of me, and with incredible accuracy and nimbleness, skipped out of the parlour and into the road, where, as I still stood motionless, I could hear his stick go tap-tap-tapping into the distance.

Then, without a word, he jerked me towards him and said, "Take me to the captain." I hesitated, for I knew the captain was in a bad way, and he always kept a cutlass drawn by his side. But the blind man only laughed, a cruel, cold laugh, and with a sudden twist of my arm, he threatened to break it if I did not obey. The voice was so full of cruelty and ugliness that it frightened me more than the pain, and I yielded at once. He leaned heavily on me, gripping me tightly, and I led him into the inn and up to the parlor where the captain sat in a drunken stupor. As we approached, the blind man said, "Call out, 'Here's a friend for you, Bill!'" and gave my arm another wrench that nearly made me faint with terror. I opened the door with a trembling voice and cried out the words. The captain looked up, and the sight of the blind man seemed to sober him at once. He stared not with fear, but with a look of deadly illness, and tried to rise, but was too weak. The blind man ordered him to sit still, saying he could see every movement despite his blindness. Then he told me to take the captain's left hand and place it in his own right hand. We obeyed, and I saw the blind man slip a small object from his stick hand into the captain's palm, which the captain immediately closed. "My business is done," said the blind man, and with a sudden burst of speed, he released me and darted out of the parlor, tapping swiftly down the road until his sound faded away, leaving me standing there, frozen.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
I held out my hand, and the horrible, soft-spoken, eyeless creature gripped it in a moment like a vise. His hand was clammy and cold, and the touch sent a shiver down my spine. The silence between us was thick, broken only by the distant crash of waves against the shore. I could feel the weight of his gaze, though his eyes were hidden beneath the shadow of his hat, and it was as if he could see right through me.

"You’re the lad they call Jim, ain’t ye?" he whispered, his voice rough but strangely gentle.

I nodded, unable to find my voice. The stories I had heard about this man, the infamous Long John Silver, flooded my mind. Yet, here he was, not the monstrous pirate I had imagined, but a man with a complex air about him.

"Aye," he said, releasing my hand slowly. "I’ve been watchin’ ye, Jim. Ye’ve got the makings of a fine seaman, and a brave heart to match."

His words surprised me, and for a moment, I felt a flicker of hope. Perhaps this journey would not be as perilous as I had feared. But then, the creak of the ship’s timbers reminded me of the dangers that lay ahead.

"We set sail at dawn," Silver continued, his voice dropping to a conspiratorial whisper. "There’s treasure to be found, and a crew to be led. But beware, Jim, for not all aboard are as loyal as they seem."

I swallowed hard, the weight of his warning settling over me. The adventure I had dreamed of was about to begin, but with it came uncertainty and peril. Yet, I was determined to see it through, to find the treasure and to prove myself worthy.

As the night deepened, I found myself standing at the ship’s prow, staring out into the vast expanse of the sea. The stars glittered above, silent witnesses to the promise of adventure and the secrets yet to be uncovered. The island awaited, with its hidden coves and buried gold, and I was ready to face whatever challenges lay ahead.

In that moment, I understood that this was more than a mere voyage; it was a test of courage, loyalty, and the human spirit. And with Long John Silver by my side, I would navigate the treacherous waters of both the sea and the heart.

events.title: The Captain's Reaction to the Black Spot and Sudden Death
detailed_summary: A period of stunned silence follows before Jim and the captain appear to recover their faculties almost simultaneously.
Jim lets go of the captain's wrist, which he had unconsciously continued to hold.
The captain retracts his hand and peers intently at its palm.
He cries out, 'Ten o’clock! Six hours. We’ll do them yet,' and then, with a burst of energy, springs to his feet.

However, this sudden movement is his last; he immediately staggers, clutches at his throat, sways precariously for an instant, and then, with a strange sound, collapses face-first onto the floor from his full height.
Jim rushes to his side, calling out for his mother, but their efforts are futile.
The captain has died instantly from what Jim understands to be a 'thundering apoplexy.'
Jim reflects on the curious fact that, despite never having liked the captain (though he had recently begun to feel some pity for him), he is overcome by a flood of tears at the sight of his death.
He notes that this is the second death he has witnessed in his young life, and the grief from the first (his father's recent passing) is still acutely painful.

segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: It was the second death I had known, and the sorrow of the first was still fresh in my heart.

events.text_segment:
It was some time before either I or the captain seemed to gather our senses, but at length, and about at the same moment, I released his wrist, which I was still holding, and he drew in his hand and looked sharply into the palm.
“Ten o’clock!” he cried. “Six hours. We’ll do them yet,” and he sprang to his feet.
Even as he did so, he reeled, put his hand to his throat, stood swaying for a moment, and then, with a peculiar sound, fell from his whole height face foremost to the floor.
I ran to him at once, calling to my mother. But haste was all in vain. The captain had been struck dead by thundering apoplexy. It is a curious thing to understand, for I had certainly never liked the man, though of late I had begun to pity him, but as soon as I saw that he was dead, I burst into a flood of tears. It was the second death I had known, and the sorrow of the first was still fresh in my heart.

It was the second death I had ever witnessed, and the grief for the first—the loss of my father—was still fresh and keen in my heart.

events.title: Fear and Decision to Seek Help
detailed_summary: Jim informs his mother about the full extent of their perilous situation concerning the deceased captain.
They recognize the danger posed by the captain's associates, like Black Dog and the blind beggar, who would likely not honor the captain's debts.
The idea of Jim leaving his mother alone to fetch Doctor Livesey, as the captain had ordered, is dismissed as too risky.
The atmosphere in the inn becomes unbearable, with everyday sounds like falling coals and the clock's ticking amplifying their fear.
They feel haunted by imagined approaching footsteps and the constant dread of the blind beggar's return, especially with the captain's corpse in the parlor.
Driven by terror, they resolve to go together to the nearby hamlet to find assistance.
Without pausing, they run out bare-headed into the evening fog.

segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Bare-headed as we were, we ran out at once in the gathering evening and the frosty fog.

events.text_segment: I lost no time, of course, in telling my mother all that I knew, and perhaps should have told her long before, and we saw ourselves at once in a difficult and dangerous position. Some of the man’s money—if he had any—was certainly due to us, but it was not likely that our captain’s shipmates, above all the two specimens seen by me, Black Dog and the blind beggar, would be inclined to give up their booty in payment of the dead man’s debts. The captain’s order to mount at once and ride for Doctor Livesey would have left my mother alone and unprotected, which was not to be thought of. Indeed, it seemed impossible for either of us to remain much longer in the house; the fall of coals in the kitchen grate, the very ticking of the clock, filled us with alarms. The neighbourhood, to our ears, seemed haunted by approaching footsteps; and what between the dead body of the captain on the parlour floor and the thought of that detestable blind beggar hovering near at hand and ready to return, there were moments when, as the saying goes, I jumped in my skin for terror. Something must speedily be resolved upon, and it occurred to us at last to go forth together and seek help in the neighbouring hamlet. No sooner said than done. Bare-headed as we were, we ran out at once in the gathering evening and the frosty fog.

events.title: The Hamlet's Cowardice
detailed_summary: They journey to the hamlet, located a short distance away but out of sight, in the opposite direction from where the blind man had appeared.
During their short walk, they pause nervously to listen but hear only natural sounds of the woods and water.
Upon reaching the hamlet, illuminated by candlelight, Jim initially feels a surge of hope.
This hope quickly diminishes as none of the villagers—men, women, or children—are willing to accompany them back to the Admiral Benbow.
The more Jim and his mother explain their predicament, the more fearful and reclusive the villagers become.
The name "Captain Flint," though unfamiliar to Jim, instills great terror in some of the villagers.
Some villagers recall seeing suspicious strangers, presumed to be smugglers, on the road near the inn, and one had spotted a small boat (lugger) in Kitt’s Hole.
The mere association with any of the captain's comrades is enough to frighten the villagers profoundly.
While several villagers offer to ride to Dr. Livesey's, which is in a different direction, none will assist in defending the inn itself.

events.text_segment:
The hamlet lay not many hundred yards away, though out of view, on the other side of the next cove; and what greatly encouraged me, it was in an opposite direction from that whence the blind man had made his appearance and whither he had presumably returned. We were not many minutes on the road, though we sometimes stopped to lay hold of each other and hearken. But there was no unusual sound—nothing but the low wash of the ripple and the croaking of the inmates of the wood.
It was already candle-light when we reached the hamlet, and I shall never forget how much I was cheered to see the yellow shine in doors and windows; but that, as it proved, was the best of the help we were likely to get in that quarter. For—you would have thought men would have been ashamed of themselves—no soul would consent to return with us to the Admiral Benbow. The more we told of our troubles, the more—man, woman, and child—they clung to the shelter of their houses. The name of Captain Flint, though it was strange to me, was well enough known to some there and carried a great weight of terror. Some of the men who had been to field-work on the far side of the Admiral Benbow remembered, besides, to have seen several strangers on the road, and taking them to be smugglers, to have bolted away; and one at least had seen a little lugger in what we called Kitt’s Hole. For that matter, anyone who was a comrade of the captain’s was enough to frighten them to death. And the short and the long of the matter was, that while we could get several who were willing enough to ride to Dr. Livesey’s, which lay in another direction, not one would help us to defend the inn.

events.title: Mother's Defiant Stand and Decision to Return
detailed_summary: Despite the widespread cowardice, Jim's mother is emboldened by argument and delivers a resolute speech to the villagers.
She declares her refusal to lose the money owed to her, especially for her fatherless son.
She firmly states that if no one else dares, she and Jim will return to the inn alone to open the captain's chest, even at the risk of their lives.
She pointedly asks Mrs. Crossley for a bag to carry their rightful earnings.
Jim confirms he will accompany his mother, and the villagers exclaim at their recklessness.
Despite their protests, no villager offers to join them.
Their only assistance is to provide Jim with a loaded pistol for protection and to promise to have horses ready for their escape if pursued.
Additionally, one young villager is dispatched to ride to Doctor Livesey's to seek armed help.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: They say cowardice is infectious; but then argument is, on the other hand, a great emboldener; and so when each had said his say, my mother made them a speech.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: All they would do was to give me a loaded pistol lest we were attacked, and to promise to have horses ready saddled in case we were pursued on our return, while one lad was to ride forward to the doctor’s in search of armed assistance.

events.text_segment:
They say cowardice is infectious; but then argument is, on the other hand, a great emboldener; and so when each had said his say, my mother made them a speech. She would not, she declared, lose money that belonged to her fatherless boy; “If none of the rest of you dare,” she said, “Jim and I dare. Back we will go, the way we came, and small thanks to you big, hulking, chicken-hearted men. We’ll have that chest open, if we die for it. And I’ll thank you for that bag, Mrs. Crossley, to bring back our lawful money in.”
Of course I said I would go with my mother, and of course they all cried out at our foolhardiness, but even then not a man would go along with us. All they would do was to give me a loaded pistol lest we were attacked, and to promise to have horses ready saddled in case we were pursued on our return, while one lad was to ride forward to the doctor’s in search of armed assistance.

She told them that she was not going to lose the money that was owed to her, and that she was a woman who had a fatherless son to provide for. She declared that if no one else would go, she and I would return to the inn alone, and open the captain's sea-chest, come what might. Then she turned to Mrs. Crossley and asked for a bag to carry our rightful earnings. I said I would go with her, and the villagers exclaimed at our recklessness. Yet, though they protested, not one offered to accompany us. Their only help was to give me a loaded pistol for protection, and to promise that horses would be ready for our escape if we were pursued. Moreover, one young man was sent off at once to ride to Doctor Livesey's for armed assistance.

The journey was perilous, but their hearts were steadfast, and their eyes fixed on the horizon.

events.title: Inside the Inn: The Black Spot and Ominous Deadline
detailed_summary: Jim's heart races as he and his mother embark on their dangerous return to the inn under a rising moon that, combined with thinning fog, threatens to expose them and increases their haste.
They move stealthily along the hedges, their fears heightened, until they safely re-enter the Admiral Benbow and bolt the door.
They pause in the darkness, breathless, alone in the house with the captain's corpse.
His mother lights a candle, and they enter the parlor together, finding the captain's body lying as they had left it, on his back with eyes open and an arm outstretched.
At his mother's whispered instruction, Jim draws the blind to prevent anyone from watching them from outside.
His mother expresses her dread and reluctance about touching the body to find the key, questioning who would do it.
Kneeling beside the body, Jim finds a small, round piece of paper, blackened on one side, near the captain's hand.
He recognizes it as the "black spot" and reads the message on the other side, written in a clear hand: "You have till ten tonight."
As Jim relays this deadline to his mother, the old clock begins to strike, startling them shockingly, but also bringing the somewhat reassuring news that it is only six o'clock.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: My heart was beating finely when we two set forth in the cold night upon this dangerous venture.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: “He had till ten, Mother,” said I; and just as I said it, our old clock began striking. This sudden noise startled us shockingly; but the news was good, for it was only six.

events.text_segment:
My heart was beating finely when we two set forth in the cold night upon this dangerous venture. A full moon was beginning to rise and peered redly through the upper edges of the fog, and this increased our haste, for it was plain, before we came forth again, that all would be as bright as day, and our departure exposed to the eyes of any watchers. We slipped along the hedges, noiseless and swift, nor did we see or hear anything to increase our terrors, till, to our relief, the door of the Admiral Benbow had closed behind us.
I slipped the bolt at once, and we stood and panted for a moment in the dark, alone in the house with the dead captain’s body. Then my mother got a candle in the bar, and holding each other’s hands, we advanced into the parlour. He lay as we had left him, on his back, with his eyes open and one arm stretched out.
“Draw down the blind, Jim,” whispered my mother; “they might come and watch outside. And now,” said she when I had done so, “we have to get the key off that; and who’s to touch it, I should like to know!” and she gave a kind of sob as she said the words.
I went down on my knees at once. On the floor close to his hand there was a little round of paper, blackened on the one side. I could not doubt that this was the black spot; and taking it up, I found written on the other side, in a very good, clear hand, this short message: “You have till ten tonight.”
“He had till ten, Mother,” said I; and just as I said it, our old clock began striking. This sudden noise startled us shockingly; but the news was good, for it was only six.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: My heart was beating finely when we two set forth in the cold night upon this dangerous venture. The moon was just rising, and the fog was beginning to thin, so that we had to be very quick and very cautious. We crept along the hedges, my mother clutching my arm, and I could feel her trembling as much as I was myself. Every rustle of the leaves, every distant sound, made us start and quicken our pace. At last we reached the Admiral Benbow, and I slipped the key into the lock and turned it. The door gave way with a creak, and we slipped inside and bolted it behind us. We stood for a moment in the darkness, breathless and alone in the house with the dead man. Then my mother struck a match and lit a candle, and we went into the parlor. There lay the captain, just as we had left him, on his back, his eyes wide open, and one arm stretched out. "Draw the blind," whispered my mother, "lest anyone should see us." I obeyed, and the room was dark again. "Oh, Jim," said my mother, "I dread to touch him. Who would do it?" But I knelt down beside the body, and near his hand I found a small round piece of paper, blackened on one side. I knew it at once—it was the black spot. I turned it over and read the message on the other side, written in a clear hand: "You have till ten tonight." I told my mother, and just then the old clock began to strike. The sound startled us both, but it was a comfort to know it was only six o'clock.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
My heart was beating finely when we two set forth in the cold night upon this dangerous venture. The moon was hidden behind thick clouds, and the sea whispered its eerie song as the waves gently rocked our small boat. Jim Hawkins, though young, showed a courage that belied his years, gripping the oars with steady hands. We had but one purpose: to reach the island where the treasure lay buried, a place shrouded in mystery and peril.

The journey was fraught with tension. Every shadow seemed to conceal a lurking danger, every rustle in the bushes a potential threat. Yet, the promise of gold and adventure spurred us onward. As we neared the shore, the silhouette of the island emerged from the darkness, its jagged cliffs rising like sentinels against the night sky.

Landing was no easy task; the rocky beach was treacherous, and the tide threatened to sweep us away. But with determination, we secured the boat and began our ascent into the dense jungle. The air was thick with the scent of salt and earth, and the cries of unseen creatures echoed around us.

We moved cautiously, aware that Long John Silver and his band of pirates might be lurking nearby, their greed as fierce as our own. The map clutched in my hand was our only guide, leading us through tangled undergrowth and over hidden pitfalls.

At last, we reached the clearing marked by the ancient oak tree, its gnarled branches stretching toward the heavens. Here, beneath the roots, lay the treasure that had driven men to madness and mutiny. With trembling hands, we began to dig, the promise of fortune shining brighter than the stars above.

events.title: Securing the Key from the Captain's Body
detailed_summary: Following the revelation from the black spot, Jim's mother prompts him to find the key.

Jim meticulously searches the captain's pockets one by one, discovering a few small coins, a thimble, some thread and large needles, a piece of pigtail tobacco bitten at the end, his gully knife with a crooked handle, a pocket compass, and a tinder box, but not the key, leading to his growing despair.
His mother suggests the key might be around the captain's neck.
Overcoming his strong revulsion, Jim tears open the dead man's shirt at the neck.
He discovers the key hanging on a piece of tarry string around the captain's neck.
Using the captain's own gully knife, Jim cuts the string to retrieve the key.

This success fills them with a sense of triumph and renewed hope, and they promptly hurry upstairs without delay to the small room where the captain had lodged and where his sea chest had been kept since his arrival.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: “Now, Jim,” she said, “that key.”
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: At this triumph we were filled with hope and hurried upstairs without delay to the little room where he had slept so long and where his box had stood since the day of his arrival.

events.text_segment:
“Now, Jim,” she said, “that key.”
I felt in his pockets, one after another. A few small coins, a thimble, and some thread and big needles, a piece of pigtail tobacco bitten away at the end, his gully with the crooked handle, a pocket compass, and a tinder box were all that they contained, and I began to despair.
“Perhaps it’s round his neck,” suggested my mother.
Overcoming a strong repugnance, I tore open his shirt at the neck, and there, sure enough, hanging to a bit of tarry string, which I cut with his own gully, we found the key. At this triumph we were filled with hope and hurried upstairs without delay to the little room where he had slept so long and where his box had stood since the day of his arrival.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction:
“Now, Jim,” she said, “that key.”

Jim took the captain’s pockets one by one, and emptied them out on the floor. There were a few small coins, a thimble, some thread and large needles, a piece of pigtail tobacco bitten at the end, his gully knife with a crooked handle, a pocket compass, and a tinder box. But no key.

“Try the neck,” said his mother.

Jim’s face turned pale, but he obeyed. He tore open the dead man’s shirt at the neck, and there, hanging on a piece of tarry string, was the key. With the captain’s own gully knife, Jim cut the string and took the key.

“Hurrah!” cried his mother. “Now we can open the sea chest.”

They hurried upstairs without delay to the small room where the captain had lodged and where his sea chest had been kept since his arrival.

events.title: Unlocking the Chest and Discovering its Treasures
detailed_summary: The sea chest appears typical for a seaman, marked with the initial "B" burned into its top with a hot iron, and its corners show damage from long, rough use.
Jim's mother takes the key and, though the lock is very stiff, she manages to turn it and throw back the lid swiftly.
A potent smell of tobacco and tar emerges from the chest's interior.
The first item they see is a suit of very good clothes, carefully brushed and folded, which his mother notes had never been worn.

Beneath the clothes, they find a diverse collection of items: a quadrant, a tin canikin, several sticks of tobacco, two braces of very handsome pistols, a piece of bar silver, an old Spanish watch, various other trinkets of little value and mostly foreign-made, a pair of compasses mounted with brass, and five or six curious West Indian shells.
Jim reflects later, wondering why the captain would carry such shells with him throughout his wandering, guilty, and hunted life.
Initially, apart from the silver and trinkets, they find nothing of significant value relevant to settling the captain's debt.

Underneath an old boat-cloak, whitened with sea-salt from many harbors, they finally uncover the most important items: a bundle wrapped in oilcloth, which looks like papers, and a canvas bag that jingles with the sound of gold coins when touched.

events.text_segment:
It was like any other seaman’s chest on the outside, the initial “B” burned on the top of it with a hot iron, and the corners somewhat smashed and broken as by long, rough usage.
“Give me the key,” said my mother; and though the lock was very stiff, she had turned it and thrown back the lid in a twinkling.
A strong smell of tobacco and tar rose from the interior, but nothing was to be seen on the top except a suit of very good clothes, carefully brushed and folded. They had never been worn, my mother said. Under that, the miscellany began—a quadrant, a tin canikin, several sticks of tobacco, two brace of very handsome pistols, a piece of bar silver, an old Spanish watch and some other trinkets of little value and mostly of foreign make, a pair of compasses mounted with brass, and five or six curious West Indian shells. I have often wondered since why he should have carried about these shells with him in his wandering, guilty, and hunted life.
In the meantime, we had found nothing of any value but the silver and the trinkets, and neither of these were in our way. Underneath there was an old boat-cloak, whitened with sea-salt on many a harbour-bar. My mother pulled it up with impatience, and there lay before us, the last things in the chest, a bundle tied up in oilcloth, and looking like papers, and a canvas bag that gave forth, at a touch, the jingle of gold.

events.title: Counting Dues and the Blind Man's Tense Approach
detailed_summary: Jim's mother asserts her honesty, declaring she will show the "rogues" that she will take only the money owed to her and not a farthing more.
She instructs Jim to hold Mrs. Crossley's bag and begins meticulously counting coins from the captain's canvas bag into it to cover his debt.

The task is protracted and challenging because the coins are of various denominations, sizes, and nationalities, including doubloons, louis d’ors, guineas, and pieces of eight, all mixed together randomly.
His mother is most familiar with counting guineas, which are relatively scarce among the coins, making her calculation process more difficult.

When they are about halfway through the counting, Jim is suddenly alarmed, placing his hand on his mother's arm, as he hears in the silent, frosty air the distinct sound of the blind man's stick tapping on the frozen road, a sound that fills him with dread.
The tapping grows nearer and nearer while they sit frozen, holding their breath.
The tapping then strikes sharply on the inn door, followed by the sound of the handle being turned and the bolt rattling as the blind man attempts to enter.
A long period of silence ensues, both inside and outside the inn.
To their indescribable joy and gratitude, the tapping eventually recommences and then slowly fades into the distance until it can no longer be heard.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: “I’ll show these rogues that I’m an honest woman,” said my mother.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: At last the tapping recommenced, and, to our indescribable joy and gratitude, died slowly away again until it ceased to be heard.

events.text_segment:
“I’ll show these rogues that I’m an honest woman,” said my mother. “I’ll have my dues, and not a farthing over. Hold Mrs. Crossley’s bag.” And she began to count over the amount of the captain’s score from the sailor’s bag into the one that I was holding.
It was a long, difficult business, for the coins were of all countries and sizes—doubloons, and louis d’ors, and guineas, and pieces of eight, and I know not what besides, all shaken together at random. The guineas, too, were about the scarcest, and it was with these only that my mother knew how to make her count.
When we were about half-way through, I suddenly put my hand upon her arm, for I had heard in the silent frosty air a sound that brought my heart into my mouth—the tap-tapping of the blind man’s stick upon the frozen road. It drew nearer and nearer, while we sat holding our breath. Then it struck sharp on the inn door, and then we could hear the handle being turned and the bolt rattling as the wretched being tried to enter; and then there was a long time of silence both within and without. At last the tapping recommenced, and, to our indescribable joy and gratitude, died slowly away again until it ceased to be heard.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction:
"I'll show these rogues that I'm an honest woman," said my mother. "I will take nothing but what is my due, not a farthing more." She then took Mrs. Crossley's bag from me and bade me hold it carefully. From the captain's canvas bag she began to count out the coins, one by one, into the smaller bag. It was a tedious and difficult task, for the coins were of all sorts and sizes—doubloons, louis d'ors, guineas, pieces of eight, and many others, all jumbled together without order. My mother was most familiar with guineas, but these were few among the heap, making her calculations slow and careful.

We were about halfway through the counting when I suddenly felt a chill run down my spine. I placed my hand on my mother's arm and listened intently. In the still, frosty air, I heard the unmistakable tapping of the blind man's stick upon the frozen road. The sound filled me with dread. We sat motionless, holding our breath as the tapping grew nearer and nearer.

Then, sharply, the tapping struck upon the inn door, followed by the creak of the handle turning and the rattle of the bolt as the blind man tried to enter. A long silence followed, both inside and outside the inn. Our hearts beat fast in the stillness.

At last, to our indescribable joy and gratitude, the tapping began again, slowly receding into the distance until it faded away entirely.

In the end, the pirates were defeated, their schemes unraveled by the bravery and cunning of those who refused to yield.

Returning home victorious, we found solace in the knowledge that honesty and courage had prevailed. The tale of our struggle became a legend, a testament to the strength of the human spirit in the face of adversity.

events.title: Interrupted Reckoning and Urgent Decision to Flee
detailed_summary: Deeply unsettled by the blind man's attempt to enter and certain that the bolted door would seem suspicious and attract more trouble, Jim implores his mother to take all the money and leave immediately.
Despite her fear, Jim's mother obstinately refuses to take a fraction more than what she believes is rightfully due to her, and she is equally unwilling to be content with less.
She argues that it is still a long way from seven o'clock, implying they have time before the "ten o'night" deadline, and insists on her rights as she knows them.
Their argument is abruptly cut short by the sound of a little low whistle from a good way off upon the hill, a clear signal of approaching danger that is more than enough for both of them.
His mother jumps to her feet, quickly deciding she will take the amount she has already counted.
Jim, seizing the opportunity, picks up the oilskin packet of papers, stating he will take it to "square the count," meaning it will serve as the remainder of their due.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: “Mother,” said I, “take the whole and let’s be going,” for I was sure the bolted door must have seemed suspicious and would bring the whole hornet’s nest about our ears, though how thankful I was that I had bolted it, none could tell who had never met that terrible blind man.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: “And I’ll take this to square the count,” said I, picking up the oilskin packet.

events.text_segment:
“Mother,” said I, “take the whole and let’s be going,” for I was sure the bolted door must have seemed suspicious and would bring the whole hornet’s nest about our ears, though how thankful I was that I had bolted it, none could tell who had never met that terrible blind man.
But my mother, frightened as she was, would not consent to take a fraction more than was due to her and was obstinately unwilling to be content with less. It was not yet seven, she said, by a long way; she knew her rights and she would have them; and she was still arguing with me when a little low whistle sounded a good way off upon the hill. That was enough, and more than enough, for both of us.
“I’ll take what I have,” she said, jumping to her feet.
“And I’ll take this to square the count,” said I, picking up the oilskin packet.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction:
“Mother,” said I, “take the whole and let’s be going,” for I was sure the bolted door must have seemed suspicious and would bring the whole hornet’s nest about our ears, though how thankful I was that I had bolted it, none could tell who had never met that terrible blind man.

“No, Jim,” said she, “I won’t take a penny more than what’s right. I know my rights, and I mean to have them. It’s not seven o’clock yet, and there’s time enough before ten o’night. I won’t be robbed, and I won’t be cheated.”

We were at it, then, when a little low whistle came from a good way off upon the hill. It was a signal, and it meant danger. It was enough for both of us.

Mother jumped up, and said she would take the amount she had counted.

I took up the oilskin packet of papers, and said I would take it to square the count.

events.title: The Escape, Pursuit, and Mother's Collapse
detailed_summary: They immediately begin their retreat, groping their way downstairs in the dark, leaving the candle by the now-empty chest, and in the next moment, they had opened the door and were in full flight.

Their departure is none too soon, as the fog is rapidly dispersing, and the moon already shines clearly on the high ground, though a thin veil of fog still conceals the immediate area around the tavern door and the first steps of their escape.
They realize that less than halfway to the hamlet, beyond the bottom of the hill, they will be exposed in the moonlight.
Their peril is compounded by the sound of several people running, coming from the direction of their pursuers.
Looking back, they see a light tossing to and fro and rapidly advancing, indicating one of the newcomers carried a lantern.
Suddenly, Jim's mother cries out that she is about to faint, a development Jim thinks will be the end for them both.
Jim internally curses the cowardice of the neighbors and blames his mother's honesty, greed, past foolhardiness, and present weakness.
By good fortune, they are at a little bridge; Jim manages to help his mother, who is tottering, to the edge of the bank.
She gives a sigh and collapses onto his shoulder.
Unsure how he found the strength, and fearing he did so roughly, Jim manages to drag her down the bank and a little way under the arch of the bridge.

He cannot move her further because the bridge is too low, allowing him only to crawl beneath it, so they are forced to remain there, his mother almost entirely exposed and both of them within earshot of the inn.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Next moment we were both groping downstairs, leaving the candle by the empty chest; and the next we had opened the door and were in full retreat.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: So there we had to stay—my mother almost entirely exposed and both of us within earshot of the inn.

events.text_segment:
Next moment we were both groping downstairs, leaving the candle by the empty chest; and the next we had opened the door and were in full retreat. We had not started a moment too soon. The fog was rapidly dispersing; already the moon shone quite clear on the high ground on either side; and it was only in the exact bottom of the dell and round the tavern door that a thin veil still hung unbroken to conceal the first steps of our escape. Far less than half-way to the hamlet, very little beyond the bottom of the hill, we must come forth into the moonlight. Nor was this all, for the sound of several footsteps running came already to our ears, and as we looked back in their direction, a light tossing to and fro and still rapidly advancing showed that one of the newcomers carried a lantern.
“My dear,” said my mother suddenly, “take the money and run on. I am going to faint.”
This was certainly the end for both of us, I thought. How I cursed the cowardice of the neighbours; how I blamed my poor mother for her honesty and her greed, for her past foolhardiness and present weakness! We were just at the little bridge, by good fortune; and I helped her, tottering as she was, to the edge of the bank, where, sure enough, she gave a sigh and fell on my shoulder. I do not know how I found the strength to do it at all, and I am afraid it was roughly done, but I managed to drag her down the bank and a little way under the arch. Farther I could not move her, for the bridge was too low to let me do more than crawl below it. So there we had to stay—my mother almost entirely exposed and both of us within earshot of the inn.

By good fortune, we were at a little bridge; I managed to help my mother, who was tottering, to the edge of the bank. She gave a sigh and collapsed onto my shoulder. Unsure how I found the strength, and fearing I did so roughly, I managed to drag her down the bank and a little way under the arch of the bridge. I could not move her further, for the bridge was too low, allowing me only to crawl beneath it, so we were forced to remain there, my mother almost entirely exposed and both of us within earshot of the inn.

Our departure was none too soon, for the fog was rapidly dispersing, and the moon already shone clearly on the high ground, though a thin veil of fog still concealed the immediate area around the tavern door and the first steps of our escape. We knew that less than halfway to the hamlet, beyond the bottom of the hill, we should be exposed in the moonlight. Our peril was increased by the sound of several people running, coming from the direction of our pursuers. LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
The house was silent except for the creaking of the floorboards beneath our feet. We moved swiftly, our hearts pounding in our chests, the shadows of the night cloaking our hurried escape. The treasure, the very prize we had sought with such fervor, lay behind us, untouched and gleaming faintly in the candlelight. Yet, the danger was too great to linger; the threat of discovery loomed like a specter, urging us onward.

As we reached the bottom of the stairs, the cool night air greeted us, a stark contrast to the stifling tension within the house. We paused briefly, catching our breath, the adrenaline slowly ebbing from our veins. The moon cast a pale glow over the landscape, illuminating the path that would lead us away from peril.

"We must be cautious," I whispered, glancing back at the house. "The treasure is ours, but only if we live to claim it."

My companion nodded, eyes gleaming with determination. "Aye, the sea holds many secrets, but none as precious as this. We'll return when the time is right, and then, the gold will be ours to keep."

With that, we melted into the night, shadows among shadows, our minds racing with plans and possibilities. The adventure was far from over; in fact, it was only just beginning. The promise of fortune beckoned, and with it, the perils that come to those who dare to seek it. But for now, survival was paramount, and the treasure would have to wait.

chapters.chapter_title: V-The Last of the Blind Man

events.title: The Buccaneers' Arrival and Initial Search of the Inn
detailed_summary: Driven by curiosity over fear, the narrator returns to a vantage point overlooking the inn.
He witnesses the arrival of seven or eight men, led by one with a lantern, running erratically.
He recognizes the blind beggar, Pew, among them, confirmed by his voice.
Pew orders his men to break down the inn door.
The men rush the Admiral Benbow, but pause, surprised to find the door already open.
Pew, impatient and enraged, shouts for them to enter immediately.
Four or five men go inside, while two stay with Pew on the road.
A cry of surprise is heard from the inn, followed by the announcement that Bill is deceased.
Pew angrily commands some to search the body and others to go upstairs for the chest.
The narrator hears the men rushing up the stairs.
Sounds of astonishment follow, the captain's room window is forcefully opened, breaking glass, and a man addresses Pew from above.
The man reports that others have preceded them and searched the chest thoroughly.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: My curiosity, in a sense, was stronger than my fear, for I could not remain where I was, but crept back to the bank again, whence, sheltering my head behind a bush of broom, I might command the road before our door.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: “Pew,” he cried, “they’ve been before us. Someone’s turned the chest out alow and aloft.”

events.text_segment:
My curiosity, in a sense, was stronger than my fear, for I could not remain where I was, but crept back to the bank again, whence, sheltering my head behind a bush of broom, I might command the road before our door. I was scarcely in position ere my enemies began to arrive, seven or eight of them, running hard, their feet beating out of time along the road and the man with the lantern some paces in front. Three men ran together, hand in hand; and I made out, even through the mist, that the middle man of this trio was the blind beggar. The next moment his voice showed me that I was right.
“Down with the door!” he cried.
“Aye, aye, sir!” answered two or three; and a rush was made upon the Admiral Benbow, the lantern-bearer following; and then I could see them pause, and hear speeches passed in a lower key, as if they were surprised to find the door open. But the pause was brief, for the blind man again issued his commands. His voice sounded louder and higher, as if he were afire with eagerness and rage.
“In, in, in!” he shouted, and cursed them for their delay.
Four or five of them obeyed at once, two remaining on the road with the formidable beggar. There was a pause, then a cry of surprise, and then a voice shouting from the house, “Bill’s dead.”
But the blind man swore at them again for their delay.
“Search him, some of you shirking lubbers, and the rest of you aloft and get the chest,” he cried.
I could hear their feet rattling up our old stairs, so that the house must have shook with it. Promptly afterwards, fresh sounds of astonishment arose; the window of the captain’s room was thrown open with a slam and a jingle of broken glass, and a man leaned out into the moonlight, head and shoulders, and addressed the blind beggar on the road below him.
“Pew,” he cried, “they’ve been before us. Someone’s turned the chest out alow and aloft.”

I knew the voice of the blind beggar, Pew, among them, and I heard him shout to his men to break down the door. They rushed to the Admiral Benbow, but stopped short, surprised to find the door already open. Pew, impatient and furious, bade them enter at once. Four or five of the men went in, while two remained with Pew on the road. Then I heard a cry of surprise from the inn, and a voice called out that Bill was dead. Pew angrily ordered some to search the body and others to go upstairs for the chest. I heard the men rushing up the stairs, followed by sounds of astonishment. Suddenly, the captain's room window was flung open with a crash of broken glass, and a man called down to Pew that others had been there before them and had thoroughly searched the chest.
