LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
“That is all clear, and, I dare say, true enough,” replied Dr. Livesey. “But what is to be done? We cannot let the treasure lie there for the taking by any scoundrel who may chance upon it.”

Jim Hawkins looked up eagerly. “Then we must go after it, doctor! We must find the treasure and claim it before the pirates do.”

Dr. Livesey nodded thoughtfully. “Indeed, Jim. But we must be cautious. The men who buried that treasure were no ordinary thieves; they were hardened pirates, and their comrades may still be lurking about.”

“I agree,” said Squire Trelawney, who had been listening intently. “We must prepare a proper expedition. A ship, a crew we can trust, and enough provisions to last us the journey.”

“Then it is settled,” said the doctor. “We shall set sail at once. But first, we must gather all the information we can about the island and the treasure’s location.”

Jim’s heart beat fast with excitement. The thought of adventure, of sailing the seas and facing danger, thrilled him beyond measure. He could hardly wait to begin.

Over the next few days, the three men made their preparations. Squire Trelawney purchased a vessel, the Hispaniola, and hired a crew. Among the men was a cook named Long John Silver, a one-legged man with a friendly smile and a sharp eye. Though he seemed affable, there was something about him that made Jim uneasy.

As the day of departure approached, the tension grew. The doctor and the squire discussed their plans carefully, while Jim kept a watchful eye on the crew. He sensed that not all was as it seemed.

Finally, the Hispaniola set sail, cutting through the waves toward the mysterious island. The voyage was long and arduous, but the promise of treasure kept their spirits high.

Upon reaching the island, they anchored the ship and began their exploration. The dense jungle and rugged terrain made progress slow and difficult. Yet, the map held by Jim guided them steadily toward their goal.

But danger was never far behind. The pirates who had once buried the treasure were not idle, and soon, Jim and his companions found themselves in a deadly game of cat and mouse, where trust was scarce and betrayal lurked in every shadow.

Through courage, wit, and determination, they faced the perils of the island, striving to claim the treasure that had long been lost to the world. And in the end, it was not just gold and jewels they found, but lessons of friendship, loyalty, and the true meaning of adventure.

events.title: Concerns of Mutiny and a Tense Accord
detailed_summary: Captain Smollett continues, stating he doesn't know who possesses the map but insists it must be kept secret, even from himself and Mr. Arrow, or he will resign his command.
Dr. Livesey interprets Smollett's demands and concerns, suggesting the captain fears a mutiny.
Captain Smollett firmly objects to Livesey putting words in his mouth, asserting that no captain would set sail if he had definite grounds to state such a fear.

He clarifies that he believes Mr. Arrow is honest, and some of the men might be too, but as captain, he is responsible for the ship's safety and every life aboard; he perceives that things are not right and requests specific precautions or his resignation, stating that is all.

Dr. Livesey, with a slight smile, references the fable of the mountain and the mouse, implying that Smollett had initially intended a more dramatic outcome or had larger complaints when he first entered, suggesting he meant more than his stated requests.

Captain Smollett acknowledges Dr. Livesey's astuteness, admitting that his original intention upon entering the cabin was to be discharged from his position, as he hadn't expected Mr. Trelawney to entertain his concerns.

Squire Trelawney interjects that if Dr. Livesey hadn't been present, he would have dismissed Smollett; however, having heard him out, Trelawney reluctantly agrees to implement the captain's desired changes, though he openly states that his opinion of Smollett has worsened.
Captain Smollett stoically accepts Trelawney's sentiment, affirming that he will fulfill his duty regardless, and then departs.

segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: And with that he took his leave.

events.text_segment:
“Well, gentlemen,” continued the captain, “I don’t know who has this map; but I make it a point, it shall be kept secret even from me and Mr. Arrow. Otherwise I would ask you to let me resign.”
“I see,” said the doctor. “You wish us to keep this matter dark and to make a garrison of the stern part of the ship, manned with my friend’s own people, and provided with all the arms and powder on board. In other words, you fear a mutiny.”
“Sir,” said Captain Smollett, “with no intention to take offence, I deny your right to put words into my mouth. No captain, sir, would be justified in going to sea at all if he had ground enough to say that. As for Mr. Arrow, I believe him thoroughly honest; some of the men are the same; all may be for what I know. But I am responsible for the ship’s safety and the life of every man Jack aboard of her. I see things going, as I think, not quite right. And I ask you to take certain precautions or let me resign my berth. And that’s all.”
“Captain Smollett,” began the doctor with a smile, “did ever you hear the fable of the mountain and the mouse? You’ll excuse me, I dare say, but you remind me of that fable. When you came in here, I’ll stake my wig, you meant more than this.”
“Doctor,” said the captain, “you are smart. When I came in here I meant to get discharged. I had no thought that Mr. Trelawney would hear a word.”
“No more I would,” cried the squire. “Had Livesey not been here I should have seen you to the deuce. As it is, I have heard you. I will do as you desire, but I think the worse of you.”
“That’s as you please, sir,” said the captain. “You’ll find I do my duty.”
And with that he took his leave.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction:
"Well, gentlemen," continued the captain, "I don't know who has this map; but I make it a point, it shall be kept secret even from me and Mr. Arrow. Otherwise I would ask you to let me resign."

"You mean to say you suspect some of the men?" said Dr. Livesey.

"I don't say that," said the captain. "I only say that I must have my orders, and that I must be obeyed."

"You are afraid of a mutiny," said the doctor.

"Don't put words into my mouth," said the captain. "No captain would set sail if he had definite grounds to state such a fear. I believe Mr. Arrow is honest, and some of the men may be too; but I am responsible for the ship and every soul aboard her. I see that things are not right, and I ask for certain precautions, or I will resign. That is all."

Dr. Livesey smiled slightly. "You remind me of the fable of the mountain and the mouse."

"I don't understand," said the captain.

"When you first came in, you meant to be discharged," said the doctor. "You thought Mr. Trelawney would not listen to you."

"You are sharp," said the captain. "That was my thought."

"If I had not been here," said Squire Trelawney, "I would have discharged you. But now I will make the changes you ask, though I must say my opinion of you has changed."

"I shall do my duty," said the captain, "whatever you think of me."

With that, he turned and left the cabin.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
The men looked at each other, some with a gleam of excitement, others with a shadow of doubt. Captain Smollett, a man of stern countenance and unwavering principles, was not one to be trifled with. His voice carried the weight of authority as he continued, "This voyage is not a mere adventure; it is a serious undertaking. We must be cautious, for the treasure we seek is coveted by many, and the seas are fraught with peril."

Dr. Livesey nodded in agreement, his calm demeanor providing a steadying influence. "Indeed, Captain. The map is our guide, but it is also a secret that must be guarded with utmost care. Trust is paramount among us."

Jim Hawkins, the young boy whose discovery of the map had set this expedition in motion, listened intently. His heart pounded with a mixture of fear and excitement. He knew that the journey ahead would test their courage and resolve.

"I understand, Captain," Jim said earnestly. "I will keep the secret, and I will do my best to help."

Long John Silver, the ship's cook and a man of many faces, smiled slyly. His one leg tapped rhythmically against the wooden floor, and his eyes gleamed with a cunning light. "Aye, Captain, secrecy is the key. But let us not forget the dangers that lurk not only on the island but among ourselves."

The captain's gaze hardened. "That is why I insist on discipline and order. Any man who threatens the safety of this crew will answer to me."

As the ship set sail towards the mysterious Treasure Island, the men prepared themselves for the trials ahead. The map, a parchment of faded ink and cryptic symbols, was locked away, its secrets known only to a trusted few. The adventure had begun, and with it, the promise of fortune and the shadow of betrayal.

events.title: Aftermath, Reflections, and Ship Reorganization
detailed_summary: Following Captain Smollett's departure, Dr. Livesey remarks to Squire Trelawney that, contrary to his expectations, Trelawney has managed to secure two honest individuals for the voyage: Captain Smollett and John Silver.

Squire Trelawney readily agrees regarding John Silver's honesty but expresses strong disdain for Captain Smollett, describing his conduct as unmanly, unsailorly, and un-English; Dr. Livesey cautiously responds, "Well, we shall see."

Upon returning to the deck, the narrator observes that the crew has already commenced the work of relocating the arms and powder, singing as they labor, while Captain Smollett and Mr. Arrow oversee the operations.

The narrator describes the newly implemented arrangements, which he personally finds agreeable; the schooner's layout has been significantly altered, with six berths created aft from part of the main hold.
These cabins are now connected to the galley and forecastle only by a narrow, sparred passage on the port side.

The original plan for these aft berths (intended for the captain, Mr. Arrow, Hunter, Joyce, the doctor, and the squire) is changed; Redruth and the narrator (Jim Hawkins) are now assigned two of these secure berths.

Consequently, Mr. Arrow and Captain Smollett are to sleep on deck in the companionway, which has been enlarged on each side to accommodate two hammocks, almost resembling a round-house, though still low.

The narrator notes that even Mr. Arrow seemed pleased with this new arrangement, speculating that perhaps Arrow also had reservations about the crew, though this is only a guess as Arrow's opinion would not be available for long.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: “Trelawney,” said the doctor, “contrary to all my notions, I believed you have managed to get two honest men on board with you—that man and John Silver.”
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Even he, perhaps, had been doubtful as to the crew, but that is only guess, for as you shall hear, we had not long the benefit of his opinion.

events.text_segment:
“Trelawney,” said the doctor, “contrary to all my notions, I believed you have managed to get two honest men on board with you—that man and John Silver.”
“Silver, if you like,” cried the squire; “but as for that intolerable humbug, I declare I think his conduct unmanly, unsailorly, and downright un-English.”
“Well,” says the doctor, “we shall see.”
When we came on deck, the men had begun already to take out the arms and powder, yo-ho-ing at their work, while the captain and Mr. Arrow stood by superintending.
The new arrangement was quite to my liking. The whole schooner had been overhauled; six berths had been made astern out of what had been the after-part of the main hold; and this set of cabins was only joined to the galley and forecastle by a sparred passage on the port side. It had been originally meant that the captain, Mr. Arrow, Hunter, Joyce, the doctor, and the squire were to occupy these six berths. Now Redruth and I were to get two of them and Mr. Arrow and the captain were to sleep on deck in the companion, which had been enlarged on each side till you might almost have called it a round-house. Very low it was still, of course; but there was room to swing two hammocks, and even the mate seemed pleased with the arrangement. Even he, perhaps, had been doubtful as to the crew, but that is only guess, for as you shall hear, we had not long the benefit of his opinion.

Trelawney looked at the doctor with a mixture of surprise and concern. "I must confess, doctor," he said, "I had my doubts, but I trusted my instincts. Silver seemed a straightforward fellow, and the other man, though rough, appeared loyal enough."

The doctor shook his head slowly. "You were too trusting, my friend. Silver is a cunning man, and his loyalty lies only with himself and his own interests."

"But what of the other man?" Trelawney asked, his brow furrowed.

"He is part of Silver's crew," the doctor replied gravely. "They have planned this mutiny carefully, and we are all in danger."

Trelawney sighed deeply. "Then we must be vigilant. I will speak with Captain Smollett and the rest of the honest men. We must prepare for what is to come."

The doctor nodded. "Indeed. We must keep our wits about us and watch for any signs of treachery."

As they spoke, the ship sailed steadily toward Treasure Island, the promise of gold and adventure shadowed by the threat of betrayal. The men aboard were unaware of the storm brewing beneath the surface, and the true test of their courage and loyalty was yet to come.

events.title: Long John Silver's Arrival and Captain Smollett's Stern Authority
detailed_summary: While everyone is engaged in relocating the powder and reconfiguring the berths, Long John Silver arrives with the last of the shore party.

Silver, agilely boarding the ship “like a monkey for cleverness,” immediately notices the ongoing work and inquires about it, expressing concern that the changes might cause them to miss the morning tide.
Captain Smollett briefly and authoritatively informs Silver that these are his orders and directs him to go below, as the crew will soon require supper.
Silver respectfully complies, touching his forelock before heading to his galley.
Dr. Livesey commends Silver to the captain, calling him a good man; Captain Smollett offers a noncommittal "Very likely, sir."
The captain continues to direct the men moving the powder, cautioning them to be careful.
Spotting the narrator, Jim Hawkins, examining the ship's swivel gun (a long brass nine-pounder), Captain Smollett sharply orders him away, telling him to find work with the cook.
As the narrator hurries off, he overhears Captain Smollett loudly declare to Dr. Livesey his intention to have no favorites on his ship.
The narrator concludes by stating that he fully shared Squire Trelawney's negative assessment of Captain Smollett at that moment, feeling a deep animosity towards him.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: We were all hard at work, changing the powder and the berths, when the last man or two, and Long John along with them, came off in a shore-boat.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: I assure you I was quite of the squire’s way of thinking, and hated the captain deeply.

events.text_segment:
We were all hard at work, changing the powder and the berths, when the last man or two, and Long John along with them, came off in a shore-boat.
The cook came up the side like a monkey for cleverness, and as soon as he saw what was doing, “So ho, mates!” says he. “What’s this?”
“We’re a-changing of the powder, Jack,” answers one.
“Why, by the powers,” cried Long John, “if we do, we’ll miss the morning tide!”
“My orders!” said the captain shortly. “You may go below, my man. Hands will want supper.”
“Aye, aye, sir,” answered the cook, and touching his forelock, he disappeared at once in the direction of his galley.
“That’s a good man, captain,” said the doctor.
“Very likely, sir,” replied Captain Smollett. “Easy with that, men—easy,” he ran on, to the fellows who were shifting the powder; and then suddenly observing me examining the swivel we carried amidships, a long brass nine, “Here you, ship’s boy,” he cried, “out o’ that! Off with you to the cook and get some work.”
And then as I was hurrying off I heard him say, quite loudly, to the doctor, “I’ll have no favourites on my ship.”
I assure you I was quite of the squire’s way of thinking, and hated the captain deeply.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: We were all hard at work, changing the powder and the berths, when the last man or two, and Long John along with them, came off in a shore-boat. He sprang aboard the ship like a monkey for cleverness, and looked about him with a quick, sharp eye. "What are you about here?" said he. "Changing the powder and the berths," said Captain Smollett. "I hope you won't be long about it, for the tide's going, and we must be off in the morning." "I hope so," said Silver, looking round. "But I don't like to be kept waiting." "These are my orders," said the captain, briefly. "Go below, Silver; the men will want their supper soon." Silver touched his forelock and went down to his galley. "A good man," said Dr. Livesey, nodding to the captain. "Very likely, sir," said the captain. "Now, men, be careful with the powder," he called out, as the men carried the barrels. I was looking at the swivel gun, a long brass nine-pounder, when the captain caught sight of me. "Off with you!" he said sharply. "Go and find the cook something to do." I hurried away, and as I went I heard the captain say loudly to Dr. Livesey, "I mean to have no favorites on my ship." I must say I shared Squire Trelawney's opinion of Captain Smollett at that moment, and I hated him with all my heart.

events.title: Departure Preparations and the Hispaniola Sets Sail with a Shanty
detailed_summary: The night before departure was chaotic with preparations and well-wishers visiting the squire.
Jim Hawkins found the work more strenuous than any night at the Admiral Benbow, leaving him extremely tired.
Despite his fatigue, Jim remained on deck, captivated by the novel sights and sounds of the ship preparing to sail before dawn.
He observed the quick commands, the boatswain's whistle, and the crew moving in the lamplight to man the capstan-bars.
A crew member requested Long John Silver, addressed as Barbecue, to sing a song.
Silver, using his crutch, readily agreed and began the familiar shanty, "Fifteen men on the dead man’s chest."
The entire crew joined in the chorus, "Yo-ho-ho, and a bottle of rum!", pushing the capstan bars with enthusiasm.
The song and the moment transported Jim back to the Admiral Benbow, imagining the old captain's voice in the singing.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: All that night we were in a great bustle getting things stowed in their place, and boatfuls of the squire’s friends, Mr. Blandly and the like, coming off to wish him a good voyage and a safe return.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Even at that exciting moment it carried me back to the old Admiral Benbow in a second, and I seemed to hear the voice of the captain piping in the chorus.

events.text_segment:
All that night we were in a great bustle getting things stowed in their place, and boatfuls of the squire’s friends, Mr. Blandly and the like, coming off to wish him a good voyage and a safe return. We never had a night at the Admiral Benbow when I had half the work; and I was dog-tired when, a little before dawn, the boatswain sounded his pipe and the crew began to man the capstan-bars. I might have been twice as weary, yet I would not have left the deck, all was so new and interesting to me—the brief commands, the shrill note of the whistle, the men bustling to their places in the glimmer of the ship’s lanterns.
“Now, Barbecue, tip us a stave,” cried one voice.
“The old one,” cried another.
“Aye, aye, mates,” said Long John, who was standing by, with his crutch under his arm, and at once broke out in the air and words I knew so well:
“Fifteen men on the dead man’s chest—”
And then the whole crew bore chorus:—
“Yo-ho-ho, and a bottle of rum!”
And at the third “Ho!” drove the bars before them with a will.
Even at that exciting moment it carried me back to the old Admiral Benbow in a second, and I seemed to hear the voice of the captain piping in the chorus.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction:
All that night we were in a great bustle getting things stowed in their place, and boatfuls of the squire’s friends, Mr. Blandly and the like, coming off to wish him a good voyage and a safe return. I found the work more than I had bargained for, and was so tired that I could hardly keep my eyes open; but I would not go below, for I was curious to see everything, and to hear the sounds of the ship preparing to sail. The boatswain was piping, and the men were running about in the lamplight, manning the capstan-bars. Presently one of the crew called out, 'Barbecue! Barbecue! Sing us a song!' and Long John Silver, leaning on his crutch, began to sing in a clear, strong voice:

"Fifteen men on the dead man's chest—
Yo-ho-ho, and a bottle of rum!"

The men took up the chorus with a will, and the capstan-bars went round with a will too. The song brought back to me the old Admiral Benbow, and I could almost hear the captain's voice joining in the chorus.

events.title: The Voyage to Treasure Island Begins with Ominous Foreshadowing
detailed_summary: The anchor was quickly raised, sails were set, and the Hispaniola started her journey, leaving the land behind.
Jim was unable to rest before the ship was fully underway towards Treasure Island.
The narrator, Jim, states he will not recount the entire voyage in detail, noting its general prosperity.
He affirms the Hispaniola was a good vessel, the crew skilled, and the captain competent.
However, Jim foreshadows that a few significant incidents occurred en route to Treasure Island which are important to relate.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: But soon the anchor was short up; soon it was hanging dripping at the bows; soon the sails began to draw, and the land and shipping to flit by on either side; and before I could lie down to snatch an hour of slumber the Hispaniola had begun her voyage to the Isle of Treasure.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: But before we came the length of Treasure Island, two or three things had happened which require to be known.

events.text_segment:
But soon the anchor was short up; soon it was hanging dripping at the bows; soon the sails began to draw, and the land and shipping to flit by on either side; and before I could lie down to snatch an hour of slumber the Hispaniola had begun her voyage to the Isle of Treasure.
I am not going to relate that voyage in detail. It was fairly prosperous. The ship proved to be a good ship, the crew were capable seamen, and the captain thoroughly understood his business. But before we came the length of Treasure Island, two or three things had happened which require to be known.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction:
But soon the anchor was short up; soon it was hanging dripping at the bows; soon the sails began to draw, and the land and shipping to flit by on either side; and before I could lie down to snatch an hour of slumber the Hispaniola had begun her voyage to the Isle of Treasure.

I was too full of excitement to sleep, and I paced the deck for a long time, watching the ship's steady progress and the changing sky. The days that followed were prosperous and uneventful; the sea was kind, the wind favorable, and the crew worked with a will. The Hispaniola was a good ship, the captain a capable seaman, and the men were skilled and experienced. I will not weary the reader with a detailed account of the voyage, for it was, in the main, a prosperous one.

Yet, though the journey was generally smooth, there were a few incidents—small at first, but significant in the end—that I must relate, for they were the first signs of the troubles that awaited us on Treasure Island.

events.title: The Incompetence and Mysterious Demise of Mr. Arrow
detailed_summary: Mr. Arrow, the first mate, proved to be more problematic than Captain Smollett had anticipated.
He lacked control over the crew, who disregarded his authority.
More seriously, Arrow began showing signs of drunkenness at sea, including a hazy look, flushed face, and slurred speech.
He was frequently sent below deck in disgrace due to his condition.
His inebriation led to accidents, periods of incapacitation in his bunk, and occasional, brief returns to sobriety and duty.
The source of his alcohol remained a persistent mystery to everyone on board, despite their efforts to discover it.
When confronted, Arrow would either laugh (if drunk) or deny drinking anything but water (if sober).
His uselessness as an officer and negative influence, coupled with his self-destructive behavior, made his eventual disappearance one dark, rough night unsurprising and not particularly mourned.
Captain Smollett drily commented that Arrow going overboard saved them the effort of formally disciplining him.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Mr. Arrow, first of all, turned out even worse than the captain had feared.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: “Overboard!” said the captain. “Well, gentlemen, that saves the trouble of putting him in irons.”

events.text_segment:
Mr. Arrow, first of all, turned out even worse than the captain had feared. He had no command among the men, and people did what they pleased with him. But that was by no means the worst of it, for after a day or two at sea he began to appear on deck with hazy eye, red cheeks, stuttering tongue, and other marks of drunkenness. Time after time he was ordered below in disgrace. Sometimes he fell and cut himself; sometimes he lay all day long in his little bunk at one side of the companion; sometimes for a day or two he would be almost sober and attend to his work at least passably.
In the meantime, we could never make out where he got the drink. That was the ship’s mystery. Watch him as we pleased, we could do nothing to solve it; and when we asked him to his face, he would only laugh if he were drunk, and if he were sober deny solemnly that he ever tasted anything but water.
He was not only useless as an officer and a bad influence amongst the men, but it was plain that at this rate he must soon kill himself outright, so nobody was much surprised, nor very sorry, when one dark night, with a head sea, he disappeared entirely and was seen no more.
“Overboard!” said the captain. “Well, gentlemen, that saves the trouble of putting him in irons.”

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: Mr. Arrow, first of all, turned out even worse than the captain had feared. He was a man who had no control over himself, and consequently none over the crew. His authority was openly disregarded, and his conduct was a source of constant embarrassment. More serious still was the fact that he took to drinking at sea, and that his drunkenness was often so marked as to be unmistakable. He would appear on deck with a hazy look in his eyes, a flushed face, and a thick, slurred speech. Frequently he was sent below in disgrace, and at times he was so incapacitated that he lay in his bunk for hours, utterly useless. Occasionally, he would rally and perform his duties for a brief spell, but these moments were rare and short-lived. The source of his liquor was a mystery to all on board, despite their efforts to discover it. When confronted, if drunk, he would laugh and make light of the matter; if sober, he would stoutly deny having tasted anything but water. His uselessness as an officer and his self-destructive habits made his eventual disappearance one dark and stormy night less a tragedy than a relief. Captain Smollett dryly remarked that Mr. Arrow going overboard saved them the trouble of formally disciplining him.

Mr. Arrow, first of all, turned out even worse than the captain had feared. He was a man of no principle, and his conduct aboard the ship was marked by a careless disregard for duty and discipline. His laziness and neglect soon became apparent to all, and the crew began to lose respect for him. The captain, though reluctant, found himself compelled to keep a close watch on Arrow, fearing that his incompetence might jeopardize the voyage.

As the days passed, the tension among the crew grew. The men whispered in corners, speculating about the treasure and the dangers that lay ahead. Jim Hawkins, the young cabin boy, observed these murmurs with a mixture of curiosity and apprehension. He had heard tales of pirates and mutiny, and the uneasy atmosphere aboard the Hispaniola only confirmed his fears.

One evening, as the sun dipped below the horizon, Jim overheard a conversation between two crew members that chilled him to the bone. They spoke of a plan to seize the ship and claim the treasure for themselves. The realization that mutiny was brewing sent a shiver down his spine.

Determined to protect the captain and the honest men aboard, Jim resolved to keep a vigilant eye on the suspicious crew members. He knew that the success of their quest depended not only on finding the treasure but also on maintaining order and loyalty among the men. The adventure was just beginning, and the young boy was about to learn the true meaning of courage and friendship.

events.title: Crew Reorganization and Introduction to Israel Hands
detailed_summary: Following Mr. Arrow's disappearance, the ship lacked a mate, necessitating a promotion from the crew.
Job Anderson, the boatswain, was considered the most suitable candidate and effectively took on the mate's responsibilities while retaining his original title.
Mr. Trelawney's previous seafaring experience proved valuable, as he often took watch during calm weather.
Israel Hands, the coxswain, is introduced as a prudent, cunning, and seasoned sailor, deemed trustworthy in critical situations.
The narrator notes Hands' close association with Long John Silver, which serves as a transition to discussing the ship's cook.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: But there we were, without a mate; and it was necessary, of course, to advance one of the men.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: He was a great confidant of Long John Silver, and so the mention of his name leads me on to speak of our ship’s cook, Barbecue, as the men called him.

events.text_segment:
But there we were, without a mate; and it was necessary, of course, to advance one of the men. The boatswain, Job Anderson, was the likeliest man aboard, and though he kept his old title, he served in a way as mate. Mr. Trelawney had followed the sea, and his knowledge made him very useful, for he often took a watch himself in easy weather. And the coxswain, Israel Hands, was a careful, wily, old, experienced seaman who could be trusted at a pinch with almost anything.
He was a great confidant of Long John Silver, and so the mention of his name leads me on to speak of our ship’s cook, Barbecue, as the men called him.

events.title: Character Study: Long John Silver's Dexterity, Influence, and Deceptive Charm
detailed_summary: Long John Silver, the ship's cook nicknamed Barbecue, ingeniously managed his mobility with a crutch, often worn on a lanyard to free his hands.
He demonstrated impressive skill in navigating the ship and performing his duties, such as cooking, even in rough seas, by wedging his crutch for support.
He had rigged lines, humorously called "Long John’s earrings," to help him cross wider deck spaces with remarkable agility.
Some crewmen who knew him previously expressed sympathy for his current physical limitations.
The coxswain informed Jim that Silver was an educated man, capable of articulate speech, and exceptionally brave.
Silver commanded respect and obedience from the entire crew, partly due to his personable approach and willingness to help individuals.
He was consistently kind to Jim, welcoming him into his impeccably clean galley, where his parrot, Captain Flint, was caged.
Silver would engage Jim in conversation, introducing his parrot, named after the infamous buccaneer, which would screech "Pieces of eight!"
Silver claimed the parrot was ancient, had witnessed immense wickedness, and sailed with notable pirates like Captain England, learning its phrases from plundered treasure ships.
The parrot also mimicked nautical commands like "Stand by to go about."

Silver would muse on the parrot's profanity, suggesting that exposure to wickedness corrupts even an innocent creature, yet his solemn demeanor in these moments convinced Jim of his inherent goodness.

events.text_segment:
Aboard ship he carried his crutch by a lanyard round his neck, to have both hands as free as possible. It was something to see him wedge the foot of the crutch against a bulkhead, and propped against it, yielding to every movement of the ship, get on with his cooking like someone safe ashore. Still more strange was it to see him in the heaviest of weather cross the deck. He had a line or two rigged up to help him across the widest spaces—Long John’s earrings, they were called; and he would hand himself from one place to another, now using the crutch, now trailing it alongside by the lanyard, as quickly as another man could walk. Yet some of the men who had sailed with him before expressed their pity to see him so reduced.
“He’s no common man, Barbecue,” said the coxswain to me. “He had good schooling in his young days and can speak like a book when so minded; and brave—a lion’s nothing alongside of Long John! I seen him grapple four and knock their heads together—him unarmed.”
All the crew respected and even obeyed him. He had a way of talking to each and doing everybody some particular service. To me he was unweariedly kind, and always glad to see me in the galley, which he kept as clean as a new pin, the dishes hanging up burnished and his parrot in a cage in one corner.
“Come away, Hawkins,” he would say; “come and have a yarn with John. Nobody more welcome than yourself, my son. Sit you down and hear the news. Here’s Cap’n Flint—I calls my parrot Cap’n Flint, after the famous buccaneer—here’s Cap’n Flint predicting success to our v’yage. Wasn’t you, Cap’n?”
And the parrot would say, with great rapidity, “Pieces of eight! Pieces of eight! Pieces of eight!” till you wondered that it was not out of breath, or till John threw his handkerchief over the cage.
“Now, that bird,” he would say, “is, maybe, two hundred years old, Hawkins—they live forever mostly; and if anybody’s seen more wickedness, it must be the devil himself. She’s sailed with England, the great Cap’n England, the pirate. She’s been at Madagascar, and at Malabar, and Surinam, and Providence, and Portobello. She was at the fishing up of the wrecked plate ships. It’s there she learned ‘Pieces of eight,’ and little wonder; three hundred and fifty thousand of ’em, Hawkins! She was at the boarding of the Viceroy of the Indies out of Goa, she was; and to look at her you would think she was a babby. But you smelt powder—didn’t you, Cap’n?”
“Stand by to go about,” the parrot would scream.
“Ah, she’s a handsome craft, she is,” the cook would say, and give her sugar from his pocket, and then the bird would peck at the bars and swear straight on, passing belief for wickedness. “There,” John would add, “you can’t touch pitch and not be mucked, lad. Here’s this poor old innocent bird o’ mine swearing blue fire, and none the wiser, you may lay to that. She would swear the same, in a manner of speaking, before chaplain.” And John would touch his forelock with a solemn way he had that made me think he was the best of men.

Aboard ship he carried his crutch by a lanyard round his neck, to have both hands as free as possible. He was a man who had lost one leg, but he managed to get about with surprising agility, using his crutch as a support. When the ship pitched and rolled, he would wedge his crutch firmly in place and go about his duties with the skill of a man twice his strength. He had rigged lines across the deck, which he called his "earrings," to help him cross the wider spaces with ease. Some of the men who had known him before his injury expressed pity for his loss, but it was clear that he had adapted remarkably well.

The coxswain told me that Silver was a well-educated man, capable of speaking with great eloquence and possessing a courage that was beyond question. He commanded the respect and obedience of the entire crew, not only through his authority but also because of his friendly and helpful nature. He was always kind to me, inviting me into his spotless galley, where his parrot, Captain Flint, was kept in a cage.

Silver would often talk to me there, introducing his parrot, which he named after the notorious buccaneer. The bird would screech out "Pieces of eight!" with startling clarity. Silver claimed that the parrot was very old and had witnessed much wickedness in its time. He said it had sailed with Captain England and had learned its phrases from the treasure ships it had plundered. The parrot also mimicked commands like "Stand by to go about."

Silver would sometimes muse on the bird's foul language, suggesting that exposure to such wickedness could corrupt even an innocent creature. Yet, in these moments, his solemn expression convinced me that beneath his rough exterior, he was a man of genuine goodness.

simple_agent_extraction_refined_1.text:
Aboard ship he carried his crutch by a lanyard round his neck, to have both hands as free as possible. When the ship pitched and rolled, he would prop himself up with his crutch, wedging it firmly under his arm or against the mast, and so manage to keep his balance and go about his work. He had rigged lines across the deck, which he called his "earrings," to help him cross the wider spaces with surprising agility. Some of the men who had known him before his injury expressed pity for his loss, but he was as active and as capable as any man aboard.

The coxswain told me that Silver was a well-educated man, capable of speaking with great eloquence and possessing a courage that was beyond question. He said Silver was a man who had been through many adventures and had a way of commanding respect and obedience from the crew, not by force alone but by his friendly and helpful nature.

Silver was always kind to me, and he often invited me into his galley, which was kept scrupulously clean and orderly. There, in a cage, sat his parrot, a great, gaudy bird with a fierce look, which he called Captain Flint. "This here," said Silver, "is the very parrot that belonged to the old Captain Flint himself."

The parrot would screech out, "Pieces of eight! Pieces of eight!"

Silver told me that the bird was very old and had seen a great deal of wickedness in its time. It had sailed with Captain England and had been aboard many a treasure ship, learning its phrases from the plundered crews. It could also mimic the commands of the ship, such as "Stand by to go about!"

Silver would give the parrot a bit of sugar, and the bird would flap its wings and scream its phrases again and again. Sometimes Silver would shake his head and say, "Aye, the poor creature has picked up a deal of bad language, no doubt from the wickedness it has witnessed."

He would look at the parrot with a kind of solemnity, and though his words were grave, there was a kindness in his manner that made me think he was a good man beneath his rough exterior.

Aboard ship he carried his crutch by a lanyard round his neck, to have both hands as free as possible. When the ship pitched and rolled, he would prop himself up with his crutch, wedging it firmly under his arm or against the mast, and so manage to keep his balance and go about his work. He was a man who had lost one leg, but he moved about the deck with surprising agility, crossing the wider spaces by means of rigged lines which he called his "earrings." These lines were stretched across the deck, and he would grasp them and swing himself from one to the other, so that he could get about as fast as any man aboard. Some of the men who had known him before his injury expressed pity for his loss, but he was as active and as capable as any man on the ship.

The coxswain told me that Silver was a well-educated man, capable of speaking with great eloquence and possessing a courage that was beyond question. "He’s a man," said the coxswain, "that’s been through a deal of trouble and come out of it all right. I’ve seen him face death without a tremor, and he’s the best man to have in a tight place."

Silver commanded the respect and obedience of the entire crew, not only by his authority but by his friendly and helpful nature. He was always ready to do a good turn for any man, and the men liked him for it.

He was always kind to me, and he often invited me into his galley, which was kept scrupulously clean and orderly. The dishes were arranged in a neat row, and the place was as tidy as a drawing-room. There, in a cage, sat his parrot, a great, gaudy bird which he called Captain Flint.

"This here," said Silver, "is the very parrot that belonged to the old Captain Flint himself."

The parrot would screech out, "Pieces of eight! Pieces of eight!"

Silver would cover the cage with a cloth, and the bird would scream again, "Pieces of eight! Pieces of eight!"

Silver told me that the bird was very old and had seen a great deal of wickedness in its time. "He’s been to the Spanish Main, and the West Indies, and the coast of Africa," said Silver. "He’s sailed with Captain England, and he’s been aboard many a treasure ship. He learned his phrases from the plundered crews, and he’s picked up a deal of bad language, no doubt."

Silver would give the parrot a bit of sugar, and the bird would flap its wings and scream its phrases again and again.

Sometimes Silver would shake his head and say, "Aye, the poor creature has picked up a deal of bad language, no doubt from the wickedness it has witnessed."

He would look at the parrot with a kind of solemnity, and then, with a grave gesture, he would say, "It’s a lesson, matey, that even the innocent can be corrupted by the wickedness of the world."

He was a cunning and resourceful man, with a tongue as sharp as a cutlass and a smile that could charm or chill, depending on his mood.

The ship, the Hispaniola, was a stout vessel, sturdy and well-armed, ready to brave the treacherous seas in search of the fabled treasure. The crew was a motley assembly of sailors, some honest men, others with shadows in their pasts, all drawn by the promise of gold and adventure. Among them, Long John Silver stood out not only for his physical peculiarity but for his undeniable leadership and charisma.

Jim Hawkins, the young protagonist, watched Silver with a mixture of fascination and unease. The old pirate's stories of the sea, his knowledge of navigation, and his easy command over the men made him both a valuable ally and a potential threat. Jim's instincts told him to be wary, yet he could not help but be drawn into Silver's world, a world of danger, loyalty, and betrayal.

As the Hispaniola set sail, the tension among the crew grew. Silver's influence was evident, his plans unfolding with the precision of a seasoned strategist. He spoke in riddles and half-truths, keeping his true intentions veiled beneath layers of charm and guile. The treasure map, a tattered and cryptic document, was the key to their quest, and Silver knew its value better than anyone.

The voyage was fraught with peril. Storms lashed the ship, and the sea seemed to conspire against them. Yet, through it all, Silver remained unshaken, his wooden leg tapping rhythmically as he paced the deck, plotting and planning. His relationship with the crew was complex; he was both a leader and a conspirator, a friend and a foe.

When the island finally came into view, the true nature of the expedition revealed itself. Silver's mutiny was afoot, and the lines between friend and enemy blurred. Jim found himself caught in the middle of a deadly game, where trust was scarce, and survival depended on wit and courage.

The treasure hunt led them through dense jungles, hidden caves, and ancient landmarks, each step bringing them closer to the coveted hoard and the dangers that guarded it. Silver's knowledge of pirate lore and his cunning proved invaluable, yet his ambitions threatened to unravel the fragile alliances.

In the end, it was a tale of adventure, betrayal, and redemption. Long John Silver, with his wooden leg and silver tongue, remained an unforgettable figure, embodying the spirit of the sea and the complexities of human nature. His story, intertwined with Jim Hawkins' coming of age, left an indelible mark on the annals of pirate legend and the hearts of those who dared to dream of treasure and freedom.

events.title: Ongoing Tensions Between Squire and Captain, and Concerns Over Crew Indulgence
detailed_summary: The strained relationship between Squire Trelawney and Captain Smollett persisted.
The squire openly expressed his contempt for the captain.
Captain Smollett, in turn, remained reserved, speaking only when addressed and then with brevity and dryness.
While admitting he might have misjudged some crew members who proved capable, and developing a fondness for the ship's sailing qualities, the captain still harbored unease about the voyage.
The squire would become visibly agitated by the captain's remarks, pacing the deck.
The Hispaniola performed well, even during difficult weather.
The crew enjoyed exceptionally generous treatment, with frequent double rations of grog and special puddings for occasions like birthdays, and a constantly available apple barrel.
Captain Smollett disapproved of this indulgence, confiding in Dr. Livesey that spoiling the crew would lead to trouble.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: In the meantime, the squire and Captain Smollett were still on pretty distant terms with one another.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: “Never knew good come of it yet,” the captain said to Dr. Livesey. “Spoil forecastle hands, make devils. That’s my belief.”

events.text_segment:
In the meantime, the squire and Captain Smollett were still on pretty distant terms with one another. The squire made no bones about the matter; he despised the captain. The captain, on his part, never spoke but when he was spoken to, and then sharp and short and dry, and not a word wasted. He owned, when driven into a corner, that he seemed to have been wrong about the crew, that some of them were as brisk as he wanted to see and all had behaved fairly well. As for the ship, he had taken a downright fancy to her. “She’ll lie a point nearer the wind than a man has a right to expect of his own married wife, sir. But,” he would add, “all I say is, we’re not home again, and I don’t like the cruise.”
The squire, at this, would turn away and march up and down the deck, chin in air.
“A trifle more of that man,” he would say, “and I shall explode.”
We had some heavy weather, which only proved the qualities of the Hispaniola. Every man on board seemed well content, and they must have been hard to please if they had been otherwise, for it is my belief there was never a ship’s company so spoiled since Noah put to sea. Double grog was going on the least excuse; there was duff on odd days, as, for instance, if the squire heard it was any man’s birthday, and always a barrel of apples standing broached in the waist for anyone to help himself that had a fancy.
“Never knew good come of it yet,” the captain said to Dr. Livesey. “Spoil forecastle hands, make devils. That’s my belief.”

Though the captain admitted that he had misjudged some of the crew, who proved to be capable seamen, and he grew fond of the ship's sailing qualities, he still harbored unease about the voyage ahead. Whenever the captain made some pointed remark, the squire would become visibly agitated, pacing the deck in frustration. The Hispaniola performed admirably, even in rough weather, and the crew were treated with exceptional generosity: they were given frequent double rations of grog, special puddings on birthdays, and a barrel of apples was always available. Captain Smollett disapproved of this indulgence and confided to Dr. Livesey that spoiling the crew in this way would surely lead to trouble.

events.title: The Apple Barrel's Foreshadowed Importance as Treasure Island Nears
detailed_summary: The narrator, Jim, reveals that the seemingly innocuous apple barrel would play a crucial, positive role in averting a treacherous disaster.
The Hispaniola was making good progress towards their island destination, having caught the trade winds.
They were now sailing directly for the island, maintaining a vigilant lookout.
It was believed to be the final day of their outward journey, with Treasure Island expected to be sighted that night or by the next morning at the latest.
The ship sailed smoothly with a steady breeze and calm seas.
The crew was in high spirits, anticipating the imminent conclusion of the first leg of their adventure.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: But good did come of the apple barrel, as you shall hear, for if it had not been for that, we should have had no note of warning and might all have perished by the hand of treachery.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: All was drawing alow and aloft; everyone was in the bravest spirits because we were now so near an end of the first part of our adventure.

events.text_segment:
But good did come of the apple barrel, as you shall hear, for if it had not been for that, we should have had no note of warning and might all have perished by the hand of treachery.
This was how it came about.
We had run up the trades to get the wind of the island we were after—I am not allowed to be more plain—and now we were running down for it with a bright lookout day and night. It was about the last day of our outward voyage by the largest computation; some time that night, or at latest before noon of the morrow, we should sight the Treasure Island. We were heading S.S.W. and had a steady breeze abeam and a quiet sea. The Hispaniola rolled steadily, dipping her bowsprit now and then with a whiff of spray. All was drawing alow and aloft; everyone was in the bravest spirits because we were now so near an end of the first part of our adventure.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing: For it was in the barrel that I found the packet of papers, which had been dropped there by one of the crew in his haste. These papers contained the secret plans of the treasure, and the names of those who were plotting to seize it by force. events.title: Jim's Accidental Overhearing of Silver's Treacherous Plot in the Apple Barrel
detailed_summary: After sunset, with his duties completed, Jim decided he wanted an apple.
He went on deck, noting the watch was positioned forward, looking for the island, and the helmsman was quietly whistling.
Jim climbed completely inside the nearly empty apple barrel.
Lulled by the ship's motion and the sound of the water, he either fell asleep or was close to it.
He was abruptly jolted when a heavy man sat down near the barrel, causing it to shake as he leaned against it.
As Jim was about to reveal himself, the man began to speak.
Recognizing the voice as Long John Silver's, Jim was instantly petrified by the first few words he heard.
Overcome by extreme fear and curiosity, he remained hidden, realizing from Silver's initial remarks that he had stumbled upon a secret that placed the lives of all loyal crew members in his hands.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Now, just after sundown, when all my work was over and I was on my way to my berth, it occurred to me that I should like an apple.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: It was Silver’s voice, and before I had heard a dozen words, I would not have shown myself for all the world, but lay there, trembling and listening, in the extreme of fear and curiosity, for from these dozen words I understood that the lives of all the honest men aboard depended upon me alone.

events.text_segment:
Now, just after sundown, when all my work was over and I was on my way to my berth, it occurred to me that I should like an apple. I ran on deck. The watch was all forward looking out for the island. The man at the helm was watching the luff of the sail and whistling away gently to himself, and that was the only sound excepting the swish of the sea against the bows and around the sides of the ship.
In I got bodily into the apple barrel, and found there was scarce an apple left; but sitting down there in the dark, what with the sound of the waters and the rocking movement of the ship, I had either fallen asleep or was on the point of doing so when a heavy man sat down with rather a clash close by. The barrel shook as he leaned his shoulders against it, and I was just about to jump up when the man began to speak. It was Silver’s voice, and before I had heard a dozen words, I would not have shown myself for all the world, but lay there, trembling and listening, in the extreme of fear and curiosity, for from these dozen words I understood that the lives of all the honest men aboard depended upon me alone.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: Now, just after sundown, when all my work was over and I was on my way to my berth, it occurred to me that I should like an apple. So I went on deck, and found the watch forward, looking out for the island, and the helmsman quietly whistling. I climbed right inside the nearly empty apple barrel, and there I lay, lulled by the motion of the ship and the sound of the water, and I was either asleep or very near it, when suddenly I was shaken by a heavy man sitting down close to the barrel, and the barrel shook as he leaned against it. I was about to speak, but the man began to talk first. It was Long John Silver's voice, and the first words he said made me as stiff as a poker. I was so frightened and curious that I did not move, and I knew at once that I had stumbled on a secret that put the lives of all the honest men on board in my hands.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing: I had been thinking of apples all day, and the thought of biting into a crisp, juicy one was very tempting. The ship's galley was quiet, the crew already settled for the night, and the only sound was the gentle lapping of the waves against the hull. I made my way to the storeroom, hoping to find a few apples left from the last port. To my delight, there was a small basket with some fresh fruit, including a couple of bright red apples. I picked one up, feeling its smooth skin and the coolness of its flesh. As I bit into it, the sweet juice burst in my mouth, and for a moment, all the worries of the voyage seemed to fade away. The taste reminded me of home, of orchards and sunny days, and I savored every bite. After finishing the apple, I felt a renewed sense of energy and contentment. With a smile, I returned to my berth, ready to rest and face whatever adventures awaited me on Treasure Island.

chapters.chapter_title: XI-What I Heard in the Apple-Barrel

events.title: Silver Recounts Pirate History and His Financial Strategy
detailed_summary: Silver clarifies his role under Captain Flint was quartermaster, not captain, and mentions losing his leg in the same naval action where old Pew lost his eyesight.

He laments the fate of the skilled surgeon who amputated his leg, hanged at Corso Castle, and expresses his belief that ships should retain their original names, citing the Cassandra and Flint's old ship, the Walrus, which he recalls being stained with blood and heavy with gold.
The youngest sailor present voices admiration for Flint, calling him the 'flower of the flock'.
Silver acknowledges Davis as a capable pirate but states his own service was first with England, then with Flint, and now he operates independently.
He reveals his financial prudence, having saved nine hundred pounds from his time with England and two thousand after Flint, emphasizing that saving, not merely earning, is crucial.

He contrasts his own financial security with the current state of England's and Flint's former crewmen, many of whom are now impoverished and serving on their current ship, having previously been reduced to begging.
Silver uses Old Pew as an example of profligacy, describing how Pew squandered twelve hundred pounds annually before ending up starving, begging, stealing, and murdering, ultimately dying destitute.
The young seaman remarks that such a life seems ultimately futile.
Silver counters that it's only futile for fools and then begins to flatter the young seaman, calling him intelligent, using the exact same compliments he had previously used on Jim Hawkins.
Jim, concealed in the apple barrel, is filled with rage upon hearing Silver's manipulative flattery directed at another, wishing he could kill him.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: No, not I,” said Silver.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: You may imagine how I felt when I heard this abominable old rogue addressing another in the very same words of flattery as he had used to myself. I think, if I had been able, that I would have killed him through the barrel. Meantime, he ran on, little supposing he was overheard.

events.text_segment:
No, not I,” said Silver. “Flint was cap’n; I was quartermaster, along of my timber leg. The same broadside I lost my leg, old Pew lost his deadlights. It was a master surgeon, him that ampytated me—out of college and all—Latin by the bucket, and what not; but he was hanged like a dog, and sun-dried like the rest, at Corso Castle. That was Roberts’ men, that was, and comed of changing names to their ships—Royal Fortune and so on. Now, what a ship was christened, so let her stay, I says. So it was with the Cassandra, as brought us all safe home from Malabar, after England took the Viceroy of the Indies; so it was with the old Walrus, Flint’s old ship, as I’ve seen amuck with the red blood and fit to sink with gold.”
“Ah!” cried another voice, that of the youngest hand on board, and evidently full of admiration. “He was the flower of the flock, was Flint!”
“Davis was a man too, by all accounts,” said Silver. “I never sailed along of him; first with England, then with Flint, that’s my story; and now here on my own account, in a manner of speaking. I laid by nine hundred safe, from England, and two thousand after Flint. That ain’t bad for a man before the mast—all safe in bank. ’Tain’t earning now, it’s saving does it, you may lay to that. Where’s all England’s men now? I dunno. Where’s Flint’s? Why, most on ’em aboard here, and glad to get the duff—been begging before that, some on ’em. Old Pew, as had lost his sight, and might have thought shame, spends twelve hundred pound in a year, like a lord in Parliament. Where is he now? Well, he’s dead now and under hatches; but for two year before that, shiver my timbers, the man was starving! He begged, and he stole, and he cut throats, and starved at that, by the powers!”
“Well, it ain’t much use, after all,” said the young seaman.
“’Tain’t much use for fools, you may lay to it—that, nor nothing,” cried Silver. “But now, you look here: you’re young, you are, but you’re as smart as paint. I see that when I set my eyes on you, and I’ll talk to you like a man.”
You may imagine how I felt when I heard this abominable old rogue addressing another in the very same words of flattery as he had used to myself. I think, if I had been able, that I would have killed him through the barrel. Meantime, he ran on, little supposing he was overheard.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction:
"No, not I," said Silver. "I was quartermaster under Captain Flint, not captain myself. I lost my leg in the same action where old Pew lost his eyesight. A surgeon, a rare hand at the knife, he was, who cut it off for me; but he was hanged at Corso Castle, poor fellow. I always thought it a pity to change a ship's name; the Cassandra was a fine ship, and Flint's old ship, the Walrus, was a good one too. I remember the Walrus well—she was stained with blood and heavy with gold."

The youngest seaman present, a lad not much older than myself, spoke up: "Flint was the flower of the flock, sir."

Silver nodded. "Aye, Davis was a good man too, but I served first with England, then with Flint, and now I sail on my own account. I've saved nine hundred pounds from my time with England, and two thousand after Flint. It's not the earning, but the saving, that counts."

He looked around the group. "Many of Flint's old crew are now poor men, serving on this ship, some of them reduced to begging before they signed on. Old Pew, for instance, was a spendthrift; he squandered twelve hundred pounds a year, and ended up starving, begging, stealing, and murdering, dying in the gutter."

The young seaman shook his head. "Seems a wasted life, sir."

Silver smiled grimly. "Only wasted for fools, lad. But you, you have the look of a clever one. Yes, clever and sharp, just like young Hawkins here."

Hidden in the apple-barrel, I clenched my fists in fury. To hear that smooth-tongued villain use the same flattering words on another, while I was trapped and unheard, made my blood boil. If I had but a weapon, I would have struck him down then and there.

"No, not I," said Silver. "I have my own plans, and they don't include being anyone's fool. You see, I've been around the block more times than I can count, and I've learned a thing or two about survival. This treasure, it's not just gold and jewels; it's a chance for a new life, a fresh start. But it won't come easy. There are dangers lurking at every turn, and trust is a rare commodity among men like us."

Jim Hawkins listened intently, the flickering firelight casting shadows on Silver's weathered face. Despite his reputation as a pirate, there was a certain honesty in his voice that Jim couldn't ignore.

"You mean to say," Jim ventured cautiously, "that you want to find the treasure, but not at the expense of your own freedom?"

Silver nodded, a sly grin spreading across his face. "Exactly. I want the gold, but I want to keep my skin too. And if that means playing both sides, so be it."

The other men around the campfire exchanged uneasy glances. Silver's words were a reminder of the precarious balance of alliances and betrayals that defined their quest.

"Well," said Captain Smollett, stepping forward, "we all have our reasons for seeking the treasure. But let it be known, any man who betrays the rest will answer to me."

Silver chuckled softly. "Aye, Captain, but remember, the sea is a harsh mistress, and she favors the cunning."

As the night deepened, plans were whispered, and loyalties tested. Jim felt a mixture of fear and excitement. The adventure was far from over, and the true nature of the men he traveled with was slowly revealing itself.

In the days that followed, the ship sailed closer to the island, the promise of treasure drawing them onward. Silver's leadership among the pirates became evident, his charisma and wit rallying them even as suspicion simmered beneath the surface.

Jim kept a watchful eye, knowing that the line between friend and foe was as thin as a blade. The island awaited, with its hidden dangers and untold riches, and the final chapter of their journey was about to unfold.

events.title: Silver Manipulates Dick and Reveals His Secured Fortune
detailed_summary: Silver elaborates on the life of 'gentlemen of fortune' (pirates), describing it as arduous and perilous but offering substantial financial rewards compared to the meager wages of ordinary sailors.

He highlights his own methodical approach to saving, distributing his wealth in various locations to avoid suspicion, unlike most pirates who quickly dissipate their earnings on alcohol and leisure before returning to sea impoverished.

Silver declares his age as fifty and his plan to retire as a true gentleman after the current voyage, asserting that he has maintained a comfortable lifestyle, indulging his desires except when at sea.
He emphasizes to Dick that his own career began humbly, as a common sailor, just like Dick's.
Dick questions Silver about the security of his accumulated wealth, suggesting it would be inaccessible if Silver cannot return to Bristol.
Silver mockingly inquires where Dick presumed his money was kept.
Dick supposes it is in banks or other establishments in Bristol.
Silver confirms it was in Bristol when they embarked, but reveals that his wife ('old missis') now possesses all of it, and that his inn, the Spy-glass, has been sold completely.
He mentions his wife is en route to meet him at an undisclosed location, which he keeps secret to prevent jealousy among the crew.
When Dick asks if Silver can trust his wife, Silver remarks that trust is a rare commodity among pirates.

Silver then boasts of his intimidating reputation, claiming that even the formidable Captain Flint was afraid of him, despite leading the most ruthless crew afloat, and assures Dick of his safety under his command.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: “Here it is about gentlemen of fortune.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Ah, you may be sure of yourself in old John’s ship.”

events.text_segment:
“Here it is about gentlemen of fortune. They lives rough, and they risk swinging, but they eat and drink like fighting-cocks, and when a cruise is done, why, it’s hundreds of pounds instead of hundreds of farthings in their pockets. Now, the most goes for rum and a good fling, and to sea again in their shirts. But that’s not the course I lay. I puts it all away, some here, some there, and none too much anywheres, by reason of suspicion. I’m fifty, mark you; once back from this cruise, I set up gentleman in earnest. Time enough too, says you. Ah, but I’ve lived easy in the meantime, never denied myself o’ nothing heart desires, and slep’ soft and ate dainty all my days but when at sea. And how did I begin? Before the mast, like you!”
“Well,” said the other, “but all the other money’s gone now, ain’t it? You daren’t show face in Bristol after this.”
“Why, where might you suppose it was?” asked Silver derisively.
“At Bristol, in banks and places,” answered his companion.
“It were,” said the cook; “it were when we weighed anchor. But my old missis has it all by now. And the Spy-glass is sold, lease and goodwill and rigging; and the old girl’s off to meet me. I would tell you where, for I trust you, but it’d make jealousy among the mates.”
“And can you trust your missis?” asked the other.
“Gentlemen of fortune,” returned the cook, “usually trusts little among themselves, and right they are, you may lay to it. But I have a way with me, I have. When a mate brings a slip on his cable—one as knows me, I mean—it won’t be in the same world with old John. There was some that was feared of Pew, and some that was feared of Flint; but Flint his own self was feared of me. Feared he was, and proud. They was the roughest crew afloat, was Flint’s; the devil himself would have been feared to go to sea with them. Well now, I tell you, I’m not a boasting man, and you seen yourself how easy I keep company, but when I was quartermaster, lambs wasn’t the word for Flint’s old buccaneers. Ah, you may be sure of yourself in old John’s ship.”

simple_agent_extraction_refined_1.text:
Here it is about gentlemen of fortune. They are a hard lot, and a dangerous, and a desperate, and a wild, and a wicked, and a cruel, and a bloody, and a thieving, and a murdering, and a piratical lot; but they are a free lot, and a bold, and a brave, and a merry, and a rollicking, and a jolly, and a jovial, and a generous, and a kind, and a true-hearted, and a faithful, and a honest, and a manly, and a gentlemanly lot. They are a hard lot, and a dangerous, and a desperate, and a wild, and a wicked, and a cruel, and a bloody, and a thieving, and a murdering, and a piratical lot; but they are a free lot, and a bold, and a brave, and a merry, and a rollicking, and a jolly, and a jovial, and a generous, and a kind, and a true-hearted, and a faithful, and a honest, and a manly, and a gentlemanly lot.

"You see, Dick," said Silver, "the life of a gentleman of fortune is a hard one, and a dangerous one, and a desperate one, and a wild one, and a wicked one, and a cruel one, and a bloody one, and a thieving one, and a murdering one, and a piratical one; but it is a free one, and a bold one, and a brave one, and a merry one, and a rollicking one, and a jolly one, and a jovial one, and a generous one, and a kind one, and a true-hearted one, and a faithful one, and an honest one, and a manly one, and a gentlemanly one."

"But, sir," said Dick, "how do you manage to keep your money? Most of the gentlemen of fortune I have heard of spend it all in drink and play, and are as poor as rats when they come back to port."

"Ah, that's where you are wrong, my lad," said Silver. "I have my own way. I save my money, and I lay it by in different places, so that no one knows the whole of it. I have a little here, and a little there, and a little yonder."

"And how old are you, sir?" asked Dick.

"Fifty years old," said Silver, "and I mean to retire a true gentleman after this voyage. I have lived comfortably, and indulged my desires, except when at sea."

"But, sir," said Dick, "if you were to be lost at sea, how would your money be safe?"

"Where do you suppose it is?" said Silver, with a smile.

"In banks, or in some place in Bristol," said Dick.

"It was in Bristol when we sailed," said Silver, "but now my old missis has it all. The Spy-glass is sold out and done with. She's on her way to meet me, but I keep the place a secret, for fear of jealousy among the men."

"Can you trust your wife, sir?" asked Dick.

"Trust among gentlemen of fortune is a rare thing," said Silver. "But I have my reasons."

"And what of Captain Flint?" asked Dick.

"Captain Flint was a terrible man," said Silver, "but even he was afraid of me. I have the best crew afloat, and I keep them in order. You need not fear while you are under my command."

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
“Here it is about gentlemen of fortune. The story begins with young Jim Hawkins, who discovers a treasure map in the chest of a deceased pirate named Billy Bones. Jim, along with Dr. Livesey and Squire Trelawney, sets out on a voyage to find the hidden treasure on the mysterious Treasure Island. They hire a ship called the Hispaniola and assemble a crew, including the enigmatic cook Long John Silver, who later reveals himself to be a cunning pirate leader.

As they reach the island, the adventure intensifies with battles, betrayals, and alliances. Jim encounters various characters, including the marooned sailor Ben Gunn, who has been living on the island for years. The pirates, led by Silver, attempt to seize the treasure for themselves, leading to a series of conflicts between the honest men and the mutineers.

Throughout the tale, themes of bravery, loyalty, and greed are explored. Jim's courage and quick thinking help the honest crew survive the dangers of the island and outwit the pirates. In the end, the treasure is recovered, but not without loss and hardship.

“Treasure Island” is a classic adventure novel that has captivated readers with its vivid characters and thrilling plot. It paints a vivid picture of the golden age of piracy and the allure of hidden riches. The story also delves into the complexities of human nature, showing how the desire for wealth can lead to both heroism and treachery.

The novel's enduring popularity has influenced countless adaptations in film, television, and other media, cementing its place as a cornerstone of adventure literature. Its memorable characters, such as Long John Silver, have become iconic figures representing the adventurous spirit and moral ambiguity of pirates.

In summary, “Treasure Island” is not just a tale of buried gold but a rich narrative about adventure, friendship, and the choices that define us. It invites readers to embark on a journey filled with excitement and danger, reminding us of the timeless appeal of stories about the quest for fortune and the human spirit's resilience.”

events.title: Dick Commits to Mutiny; Israel Hands Expresses Impatience
detailed_summary: Dick confesses to Silver that he was initially apprehensive about their mutinous undertaking but, after their conversation, is now fully committed, sealing his pledge with a handshake.
Silver commends Dick for his bravery and intelligence, shaking his hand so vigorously that the apple barrel where Jim is hiding trembles.
Jim, overhearing this exchange, fully grasps that 'gentleman of fortune' is a euphemism for pirate and realizes he has witnessed the final stage of an honest sailor's corruption.
Silver then whistles, summoning a third man, who is revealed to be Israel Hands, the ship's coxswain.
Silver informs Hands that Dick has joined their conspiracy ('Dick's square').
Hands acknowledges Dick's allegiance, remarking that Dick is not a fool.

Hands then voices his impatience, complaining about Captain Smollett's command and questioning how long they must wait before seizing control of the ship and its desirable stores, such as pickles and wine.
Silver admonishes Israel for his poor judgment, instructing him to remain in his designated area, maintain a low profile, and stay sober until he gives the order to act.
Israel grumbles in reluctant agreement but persists in asking when they will proceed with their plan.

events.text_segment:
“Well, I tell you now,” replied the lad, “I didn’t half a quarter like the job till I had this talk with you, John; but there’s my hand on it now.”
“And a brave lad you were, and smart too,” answered Silver, shaking hands so heartily that all the barrel shook, “and a finer figurehead for a gentleman of fortune I never clapped my eyes on.”
By this time I had begun to understand the meaning of their terms. By a “gentleman of fortune” they plainly meant neither more nor less than a common pirate, and the little scene that I had overheard was the last act in the corruption of one of the honest hands—perhaps of the last one left aboard. But on this point I was soon to be relieved, for Silver giving a little whistle, a third man strolled up and sat down by the party.
“Dick’s square,” said Silver.
“Oh, I know’d Dick was square,” returned the voice of the coxswain, Israel Hands. “He’s no fool, is Dick.” And he turned his quid and spat. “But look here,” he went on, “here’s what I want to know, Barbecue: how long are we a-going to stand off and on like a blessed bumboat? I’ve had a’most enough o’ Cap’n Smollett; he’s hazed me long enough, by thunder! I want to go into that cabin, I do. I want their pickles and wines, and that.”
“Israel,” said Silver, “your head ain’t much account, nor ever was. But you’re able to hear, I reckon; leastways, your ears is big enough. Now, here’s what I say: you’ll berth forward, and you’ll live hard, and you’ll speak soft, and you’ll keep sober till I give the word; and you may lay to that, my son.”
“Well, I don’t say no, do I?” growled the coxswain. “What I say is, when? That’s what I say.”

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction:
“Well, I tell you now,” replied the lad, “I didn’t half a quarter like the job till I had this talk with you, John; but there’s my hand on it now.”

“Bravo, Dick!” said Silver, shaking the boy’s hand so heartily that the apple-barrel in which I was crouching rocked to and fro. “Bravo, my lad! You’re a brave fellow, and a sharp one. I like you, Dick.”

I, Jim Hawkins, crouched in the barrel, and heard every word. I understood now that the 'gentleman of fortune' was a pirate, and that I had been listening to the last stage of a sailor’s corruption.

Silver whistled softly, and a third man appeared—a tall, broad-shouldered fellow with a weather-beaten face and a look of hard experience. It was Israel Hands, the ship’s coxswain.

“Hands,” said Silver, “Dick’s square.”

Hands nodded. “No fool, that one.”

“Now, Hands,” said Silver, “how long are we to wait? Captain Smollett’s a hard man, and the ship’s stores—pickles, wine, and the like—are ripe for the taking.”

Hands grumbled, “Aye, but how long before we strike? I’m sick of waiting.”

Silver laid a hand on his shoulder. “Patience, Israel. Keep to your post, keep your head clear, and don’t touch a drop till I give the word.”

Hands muttered reluctantly, but the eagerness in his eyes betrayed his impatience.
