LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
I had made up my mind to run away to sea, and the very next day I set about making my preparations. I was not long in finding a ship, for the Admiral Benbow was a snug little inn, and the captain, a kind-hearted man, was willing to take me on as cabin boy. I was to have my food and lodging, and a small wage, which was more than I had ever earned before. The thought of the sea, the ship, and the adventure filled me with a wild excitement that I could hardly contain.

On the morning of our departure, I went down to the inn to say goodbye to my mother. She was a good woman, and though she did not understand my longing for the sea, she kissed me and wished me well. I promised to write to her whenever I could, and with a heart full of hope and a head full of dreams, I set off to join the crew.

The ship was a stout little vessel, and the crew were a rough but hearty lot. Among them was a man named Long John Silver, the cook, who had a wooden leg and a smile that was both friendly and cunning. He took a liking to me, and I to him, though I could not have guessed then the part he would play in the adventures to come.

As we set sail, the shore faded into the distance, and the vast ocean stretched out before us. I felt a thrill of freedom and anticipation. Little did I know that this voyage would lead me to buried treasure, mutiny, and danger beyond my wildest imaginings. But for now, I was just a boy at sea, ready to face whatever lay ahead.

events.title: Navigating the Unruly Coracle to the Hispaniola
detailed_summary: The narrator, Jim Hawkins, described the coracle as buoyant and seaworthy but incredibly difficult to steer, constantly tending to spin or drift off course.
He noted that even Ben Gunn, its previous owner, found it tricky.
Jim struggled to control the vessel, which often moved broadside, and he believed he would have failed to reach the Hispaniola if not for the favorable tide.
The tide consistently carried him towards the ship, irrespective of his paddling efforts.
The Hispaniola initially appeared as a dark mass, then its spars and hull became distinguishable.
With the current growing stronger, he quickly found himself alongside the ship's hawser and managed to grab hold of it.
He observed the hawser was stretched tight by the strong current, which gurgled around the ship's hull like a mountain stream.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: The coracle—as I had ample reason to know before I was done with her—was a very safe boat for a person of my height and weight, both buoyant and clever in a seaway; but she was the most cross-grained, lop-sided craft to manage.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: One cut with my sea-gully and the Hispaniola would go humming down the tide.

events.text_segment:
The coracle—as I had ample reason to know before I was done with her—was a very safe boat for a person of my height and weight, both buoyant and clever in a seaway; but she was the most cross-grained, lop-sided craft to manage. Do as you pleased, she always made more leeway than anything else, and turning round and round was the manoeuvre she was best at. Even Ben Gunn himself has admitted that she was “queer to handle till you knew her way.”
Certainly I did not know her way. She turned in every direction but the one I was bound to go; the most part of the time we were broadside on, and I am very sure I never should have made the ship at all but for the tide. By good fortune, paddle as I pleased, the tide was still sweeping me down; and there lay the Hispaniola right in the fairway, hardly to be missed.
First she loomed before me like a blot of something yet blacker than darkness, then her spars and hull began to take shape, and the next moment, as it seemed (for, the farther I went, the brisker grew the current of the ebb), I was alongside of her hawser and had laid hold.
The hawser was as taut as a bowstring, and the current so strong she pulled upon her anchor. All round the hull, in the blackness, the rippling current bubbled and chattered like a little mountain stream. One cut with my sea-gully and the Hispaniola would go humming down the tide.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: The coracle—as I had ample reason to know before I was done with her—was a very safe boat for a person of my height and weight, both buoyant and clever in a seaway; but she was the most cross-grained, lop-sided craft to manage. She was always tending to spin round and round, or to drift off to one side or the other, and I found it a hard matter to keep her straight. Even Ben Gunn, who had been used to her, had told me she was a tricky boat to handle. I was constantly on the watch, paddling and steering, but the coracle would not obey me as I wished. She would often lie broadside to the tide, and I was afraid I should never reach the Hispaniola if the tide did not help me. But the tide was with me, and it carried me steadily towards the ship, no matter how I paddled. At first, the Hispaniola looked like a dark mass on the water, but as I drew nearer, I could make out her spars and hull. The current was growing stronger, and before long I found myself alongside the ship's hawser. I seized it quickly, and felt the strain of the rope, stretched tight by the swift current, which gurgled and swirled around the ship's hull like a mountain stream.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing: The coracle—as I had ample reason to know before I was done with her—was a very safe boat for a person of my height and weight, both buoyant and clever in a seaway; but she was the most cross-grained, lop-sided craft to manage. She would not keep a straight course for a moment, but was always veering to one side or the other, and required constant attention and correction. I had to learn to handle her with a light hand and a quick eye, for she was as sensitive as a living thing, and would respond to the slightest touch or movement. The wind and the waves played upon her in a way that made her seem alive, and I grew to respect her as a companion rather than a mere vessel. As I paddled along the shore, I could see the cliffs rising steeply above me, their jagged edges casting long shadows in the fading light. The sea was calm now, but I knew that it could turn fierce and unforgiving at any moment. I kept my eyes on the horizon, alert for any sign of danger, and felt a thrill of adventure coursing through my veins. This was the life I had chosen, and I was determined to see it through to the end, no matter what challenges lay ahead.

events.title: The Calculated Risk of Severing the Anchor Line
detailed_summary: Jim initially felt a sense of accomplishment, but then he remembered the significant danger involved in cutting a taut hawser, comparing the potential recoil to that of a kicking horse.
He feared that such an action could result in himself and the coracle being violently thrown out of the water.
This daunting thought nearly made him abandon his plan entirely.
However, a fortunate change in wind direction, shifting to the south-west after nightfall, caused the Hispaniola to move slightly.
This movement created a momentary slack in the hawser, which Jim felt as his hand holding it dipped underwater.

Seizing this opportunity, he resolved to proceed with his plan, retrieved his knife, managed to open it using his teeth, and began cutting through the hawser's strands one by one until only two remained.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: So far so good, but it next occurred to my recollection that a taut hawser, suddenly cut, is a thing as dangerous as a kicking horse.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: With that I made my mind up, took out my gully, opened it with my teeth, and cut one strand after another, till the vessel swung only by two.

events.text_segment:
So far so good, but it next occurred to my recollection that a taut hawser, suddenly cut, is a thing as dangerous as a kicking horse. Ten to one, if I were so foolhardy as to cut the Hispaniola from her anchor, I and the coracle would be knocked clean out of the water.
This brought me to a full stop, and if fortune had not again particularly favoured me, I should have had to abandon my design. But the light airs which had begun blowing from the south-east and south had hauled round after nightfall into the south-west. Just while I was meditating, a puff came, caught the Hispaniola, and forced her up into the current; and to my great joy, I felt the hawser slacken in my grasp, and the hand by which I held it dip for a second under water.
With that I made my mind up, took out my gully, opened it with my teeth, and cut one strand after another, till the vessel swung only by two.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing: I had been leaning over the side of the ship, watching the men at work, when the rope snapped with a sharp crack. The sudden release sent the heavy cable whipping through the air like a living thing, striking with a force that could break bones. I stumbled back, heart pounding, narrowly avoiding the deadly lash. The sailors shouted warnings, scrambling to secure the lines and prevent further accidents. The tension in the air was palpable, a mix of fear and adrenaline. It was a stark reminder of the perils that lurked not only in the open sea but also in the very rigging that kept the ship afloat. From that moment, I understood the true danger of a taut hawser suddenly cut, and the respect it commanded among seasoned seamen.

events.title: Eavesdropping on the Drunken Pirates' Quarrel
detailed_summary: As Jim waited for another gust of wind to ease the tension on the last two strands of the hawser, his attention was drawn to loud voices coming from the Hispaniola's cabin.
He identified one voice as belonging to Israel Hands, who had been Flint's gunner, and the other as the pirate known for wearing a red night-cap.
It was clear that both men were heavily intoxicated and still drinking; Jim even heard one of them throw what he presumed was an empty bottle out of the stern window.

The pirates were not merely drunk but also furiously angry, their argument punctuated by oaths and escalating to what seemed like the brink of physical violence, although each flare-up would subside without blows.
Jim could also perceive the glow of the pirates' large campfire on the shore and hear a mournful, droning sailor's song being sung.
He recalled some of the song's despondent lyrics about a sole survivor of a large crew and considered it uncomfortably appropriate given the pirates' significant losses earlier that day.
He reflected on the buccaneers' apparent insensitivity and hard-heartedness, likening their nature to the unforgiving sea.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Then I lay quiet, waiting to sever these last when the strain should be once more lightened by a breath of wind.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: But, indeed, from what I saw, all these buccaneers were as callous as the sea they sailed on.

events.text_segment:
Then I lay quiet, waiting to sever these last when the strain should be once more lightened by a breath of wind.
All this time I had heard the sound of loud voices from the cabin, but to say truth, my mind had been so entirely taken up with other thoughts that I had scarcely given ear. Now, however, when I had nothing else to do, I began to pay more heed.
One I recognized for the coxswain’s, Israel Hands, that had been Flint’s gunner in former days. The other was, of course, my friend of the red night-cap. Both men were plainly the worse of drink, and they were still drinking, for even while I was listening, one of them, with a drunken cry, opened the stern window and threw out something, which I divined to be an empty bottle. But they were not only tipsy; it was plain that they were furiously angry. Oaths flew like hailstones, and every now and then there came forth such an explosion as I thought was sure to end in blows. But each time the quarrel passed off and the voices grumbled lower for a while, until the next crisis came and in its turn passed away without result.
On shore, I could see the glow of the great camp-fire burning warmly through the shore-side trees. Someone was singing, a dull, old, droning sailor’s song, with a droop and a quaver at the end of every verse, and seemingly no end to it at all but the patience of the singer. I had heard it on the voyage more than once and remembered these words: “But one man of her crew alive, What put to sea with seventy-five.”
And I thought it was a ditty rather too dolefully appropriate for a company that had met such cruel losses in the morning. But, indeed, from what I saw, all these buccaneers were as callous as the sea they sailed on.

But while I waited, my ears were caught by a noise from the cabin of the Hispaniola. It was a loud and angry voice, and I knew it at once for Israel Hands, the man who had been Flint's gunner. Another voice answered him, hoarse and thick with drink, and I recognized it as the friend of the red night-cap. They were both drunk, and still drinking, for I heard the rattle of bottles and the crash of one thrown out of the stern window. Their quarrel was fierce and full of oaths, and though it seemed to threaten blows, it never quite came to that. The voices rose and fell, and I could see the glow of their great campfire on the shore, and hear a mournful sailor's song, a droning chant of a man who had lost all his comrades and was left alone. The words were sad and fit the mood of the day, for many of the pirates had fallen, and those who remained were hard and cruel, like the sea itself.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
But the wind held, and the silence grew heavy around me. The ship creaked and groaned as if it too were holding its breath, waiting for the storm to break or the calm to return. I could hear the distant roll of thunder, a low rumble that seemed to echo the turmoil in my own heart. The ropes bit into my hands, rough and unyielding, but I dared not loosen my grip. Every muscle in my body was tense, ready to spring into action at the slightest change.

Suddenly, a faint breeze stirred the sails, a whisper of hope in the oppressive stillness. I seized the moment, pulling hard on the ropes, feeling the strain lessen as the sails caught the wind once more. The ship lurched forward, cutting through the waves with renewed vigor. Relief flooded through me, mingling with the adrenaline that kept me alert.

Around me, the crew moved with purpose, their faces set and determined. We were bound together by a common goal, each of us playing our part in the dance with the sea and the storm. The horizon began to lighten, the first hints of dawn breaking through the dark clouds. It was a new day, a chance to set our course true and chase the treasure that lay hidden beyond the horizon.

As the sun rose, casting golden light over the restless waters, I felt a surge of hope and resolve. The dangers ahead were many, but so were the rewards. With the wind at our backs and the map in my hand, I was ready to face whatever lay ahead. Treasure Island awaited, and with it, the promise of adventure and fortune beyond imagining.

events.title: Setting the Hispaniola Adrift and Witnessing a Deadly Confrontation
detailed_summary: When the wind picked up again, causing the hawser to loosen, Jim exerted himself and successfully cut the final two strands, setting the Hispaniola adrift.
The coracle, barely influenced by the breeze, was almost instantly swept against the Hispaniola's bows.
The schooner then began to slowly rotate, turning across the current.
Jim worked desperately to prevent the coracle from being swamped, eventually managing to push it clear by shoving directly astern of the larger vessel.
Just as he gave the final push, his hands encountered a light rope trailing from the Hispaniola's stern.
Acting primarily on instinct, he grabbed it; finding it secure, his curiosity then prompted him to attempt a look through the cabin window.
He carefully pulled himself along the rope and, at considerable risk, raised himself just enough to peer into the cabin.
By this point, both vessels were moving quickly, already abreast of the pirates' campfire on shore, and the Hispaniola was making significant noise as it moved through the water.
A single, brief glance revealed that Israel Hands and his companion were locked in a desperate, physical struggle, each with his hands on the other's throat, explaining why no alarm had been raised.

Jim quickly dropped back into the coracle, narrowly avoiding falling overboard, the vivid image of the two enraged, flushed faces fighting under the dim lamplight imprinted in his mind; he closed his eyes to re-acclimate to the darkness.

segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: I shut my eyes to let them grow once more familiar with the darkness.

events.text_segment:
At last the breeze came; the schooner sidled and drew nearer in the dark; I felt the hawser slacken once more, and with a good, tough effort, cut the last fibres through.
The breeze had but little action on the coracle, and I was almost instantly swept against the bows of the Hispaniola. At the same time, the schooner began to turn upon her heel, spinning slowly, end for end, across the current.
I wrought like a fiend, for I expected every moment to be swamped; and since I found I could not push the coracle directly off, I now shoved straight astern. At length I was clear of my dangerous neighbour, and just as I gave the last impulsion, my hands came across a light cord that was trailing overboard across the stern bulwarks. Instantly I grasped it.
Why I should have done so I can hardly say. It was at first mere instinct, but once I had it in my hands and found it fast, curiosity began to get the upper hand, and I determined I should have one look through the cabin window.
I pulled in hand over hand on the cord, and when I judged myself near enough, rose at infinite risk to about half my height and thus commanded the roof and a slice of the interior of the cabin.
By this time the schooner and her little consort were gliding pretty swiftly through the water; indeed, we had already fetched up level with the camp-fire. The ship was talking, as sailors say, loudly, treading the innumerable ripples with an incessant weltering splash; and until I got my eye above the window-sill I could not comprehend why the watchmen had taken no alarm. One glance, however, was sufficient; and it was only one glance that I durst take from that unsteady skiff. It showed me Hands and his companion locked together in deadly wrestle, each with a hand upon the other’s throat.
I dropped upon the thwart again, none too soon, for I was near overboard. I could see nothing for the moment but these two furious, encrimsoned faces swaying together under the smoky lamp, and I shut my eyes to let them grow once more familiar with the darkness.

At last the breeze came; the schooner sidled and drew nearer in the dark; I felt the hawser slacken once more, and with a good, tough effort, cut the last fibres through. The ship swung free, and I was alone on the island once more, with the night closing in and the sea whispering its secrets around me. The moon, a thin crescent, cast a pale light over the sands, and the shadows of the trees danced in the gentle wind. I knew that the adventure was far from over; the treasure was still out there, buried beneath the earth, guarded by the memories of those who had sought it before me.

I made my way back to the stockade, my heart pounding with a mixture of fear and excitement. The men were restless, their faces etched with the strain of the long days and nights. Jim Hawkins, brave and resolute, stood watch by the gate, his eyes scanning the horizon for any sign of the enemy. We had to be vigilant; the pirates were cunning and desperate, and the island was a place of danger and deceit.

As dawn broke, the golden light revealed the rugged landscape, the dense woods, and the rocky shores. The treasure map, with its cryptic markings and faded lines, was our guide, but it was the courage and loyalty of the crew that would see us through. We prepared for the final push, knowing that the greatest challenges lay ahead. The story of Treasure Island was one of adventure, betrayal, and the unyielding quest for gold, a tale that would be told for generations to come.

events.title: Adrift and at the Mercy of the Current
detailed_summary: Jim heard the pirates ashore conclude their song and launch into their familiar, rousing chorus.
He was musing on the aptness of the
drink and the devil
line regarding the situation in the Hispaniola's cabin when his coracle suddenly lurched, veered sharply, and began to accelerate.
Opening his eyes, he observed small, glowing ripples around him and noticed the Hispaniola ahead also seemed to be changing course erratically, heading southward.

A look astern confirmed his fears: the campfire was now behind him, revealing that the current had abruptly changed direction, sweeping both the schooner and his coracle rapidly through the narrows toward the open sea.
The Hispaniola then yawed violently, and shouts from aboard indicated that the two fighting pirates had finally been interrupted and become aware of their ship's uncontrolled drift.
Terrified, Jim lay flat in the bottom of the coracle, prayed, and resigned himself to what he believed would be a swift death on unseen breakers at the sea entrance of the straits.
He endured hours of being tossed by waves and soaked by spray, constantly expecting his demise, yet unable to bear watching it approach.
Eventually, overwhelming weariness, numbness, and intermittent stupor dulled his terror, and he succumbed to sleep, dreaming of his home and the Admiral Benbow inn amidst the chaos.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: The endless ballad had come to an end at last, and the whole diminished company about the camp-fire had broken into the chorus I had heard so often: “Fifteen men on the dead man’s chest—Yo-ho-ho, and a bottle of rum! Drink and the devil had done for the rest—Yo-ho-ho, and a bottle of rum!”
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Gradually weariness grew upon me; a numbness, an occasional stupor, fell upon my mind even in the midst of my terrors, until sleep at last supervened and in my sea-tossed coracle I lay and dreamed of home and the old Admiral Benbow.

events.text_segment:
The endless ballad had come to an end at last, and the whole diminished company about the camp-fire had broken into the chorus I had heard so often: “Fifteen men on the dead man’s chest—Yo-ho-ho, and a bottle of rum! Drink and the devil had done for the rest—Yo-ho-ho, and a bottle of rum!”
I was just thinking how busy drink and the devil were at that very moment in the cabin of the Hispaniola, when I was surprised by a sudden lurch of the coracle. At the same moment, she yawed sharply and seemed to change her course. The speed in the meantime had strangely increased.
I opened my eyes at once. All round me were little ripples, combing over with a sharp, bristling sound and slightly phosphorescent. The Hispaniola herself, a few yards in whose wake I was still being whirled along, seemed to stagger in her course, and I saw her spars toss a little against the blackness of the night; nay, as I looked longer, I made sure she also was wheeling to the southward.
I glanced over my shoulder, and my heart jumped against my ribs. There, right behind me, was the glow of the camp-fire. The current had turned at right angles, sweeping round along with it the tall schooner and the little dancing coracle; ever quickening, ever bubbling higher, ever muttering louder, it went spinning through the narrows for the open sea.
Suddenly the schooner in front of me gave a violent yaw, turning, perhaps, through twenty degrees; and almost at the same moment one shout followed another from on board; I could hear feet pounding on the companion ladder and I knew that the two drunkards had at last been interrupted in their quarrel and awakened to a sense of their disaster.
I lay down flat in the bottom of that wretched skiff and devoutly recommended my spirit to its Maker. At the end of the straits, I made sure we must fall into some bar of raging breakers, where all my troubles would be ended speedily; and though I could, perhaps, bear to die, I could not bear to look upon my fate as it approached.
So I must have lain for hours, continually beaten to and fro upon the billows, now and again wetted with flying sprays, and never ceasing to expect death at the next plunge. Gradually weariness grew upon me; a numbness, an occasional stupor, fell upon my mind even in the midst of my terrors, until sleep at last supervened and in my sea-tossed coracle I lay and dreamed of home and the old Admiral Benbow.

simple_agent_extraction_refined_1.text:
The endless ballad had come to an end at last, and the whole diminished company about the camp-fire had broken into the chorus I had heard so often: “Fifteen men on the dead man’s chest—Yo-ho-ho, and a bottle of rum! Drink and the devil had done for the rest—Yo-ho-ho, and a bottle of rum!”

The song was finished, and the voices died away, when suddenly my coracle lurched, and I was thrown forward. I opened my eyes, and saw the water all about me, and the little ripples that had been so still and quiet, now glowing faintly and moving with a strange, restless motion. The Hispaniola ahead was no longer steady on her course, but seemed to be veering and yawing, her spars showing dark against the night sky, and her course shifting southward.

I looked astern, and there, where the camp-fire had been, was now only darkness. The current had changed, and was running swiftly the other way, carrying both the schooner and my coracle with it through the narrows, and out toward the open sea. The water bubbled and muttered, and the speed of the current increased, sweeping us along with a force that was terrible to feel.

Suddenly the Hispaniola yawed violently, and I heard shouts and footsteps on deck. The two fighting pirates had been interrupted, and were now aware of the ship’s uncontrolled drift. Their voices rose in alarm and confusion.

I lay flat in the bottom of the coracle, my heart beating fast, and my limbs trembling. I prayed silently, and recommended my spirit to its Maker. I was sure that the next moment would be my last, dashed upon the unseen breakers at the entrance of the straits.

For hours I was tossed about by the waves, drenched by the spray, and rocked by the swell. I dared not look, but I could feel the peril drawing near. Weariness crept over me, and numbness dulled my senses. At times I was half-stunned, and at last I fell into a troubled sleep, dreaming of my home and the Admiral Benbow inn, while the sea still tossed me in its cruel embrace.

The words rang out clear and strong in the still night air, mingling with the crackle of the fire and the distant hoot of an owl. The men, ragged and worn from their long voyage and the perils they had faced, seemed momentarily lifted from their hardships by the familiar refrain. It was a song that bound them together, a grim reminder of the fate that awaited those who dared to seek the treasure of the infamous Captain Flint.

As the last echoes of the chorus faded, silence fell over the camp. The men exchanged glances, their faces illuminated by the flickering flames, each lost in thoughts of the adventure that lay ahead. The map, a tattered and cryptic parchment, was the key to untold riches, but also to danger and betrayal.

I, Jim Hawkins, felt a mixture of excitement and dread. The journey had already tested my courage and resolve, and I knew that the trials were far from over. The island loomed in the distance, a shadowy silhouette against the star-studded sky, promising both fortune and peril.

The night deepened, and one by one, the men settled down to rest, their bodies weary but their spirits restless. I remained awake, staring into the fire, pondering the tales of pirates and buried gold that had filled my childhood dreams. Now, those tales were reality, and the line between friend and foe was as thin as the edge of a cutlass.

Tomorrow would bring new challenges, alliances forged and broken, and the relentless pursuit of the treasure that had claimed so many lives. But for now, the song lingered in my mind, a haunting melody of the sea, of adventure, and of the deadly price of greed.

events.title: Awakening Adrift and the Perilous Southern Shore
detailed_summary: The narrator awakens to find himself adrift off the south-west coast of Treasure Island, near the imposing Spy-glass mountain.
He observes Haulbowline Head and Mizzenmast Hill, noting the dangerous cliffs and powerful breakers among fallen rocks.
His initial idea to paddle ashore is quickly abandoned due to the treacherous conditions and the fear of being dashed against the rocks or failing to scale the cliffs.
He is further deterred by the sight of numerous large sea creatures, which he initially perceives as "slimy monsters," making loud barking noises on the rocks and in the water.

Although he later learns they are harmless sea lions, their appearance, combined with the difficult shoreline and strong surf, convinces him to avoid this landing spot, preferring starvation at sea over such dangers.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: It was broad day when I awoke and found myself tossing at the south-west end of Treasure Island.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: I felt willing rather to starve at sea than to confront such perils.

events.text_segment:
It was broad day when I awoke and found myself tossing at the south-west end of Treasure Island. The sun was up but was still hid from me behind the great bulk of the Spy-glass, which on this side descended almost to the sea in formidable cliffs.
Haulbowline Head and Mizzenmast Hill were at my elbow, the hill bare and dark, the head bound with cliffs forty or fifty feet high and fringed with great masses of fallen rock. I was scarce a quarter of a mile to seaward, and it was my first thought to paddle in and land.
That notion was soon given over. Among the fallen rocks the breakers spouted and bellowed; loud reverberations, heavy sprays flying and falling, succeeded one another from second to second; and I saw myself, if I ventured nearer, dashed to death upon the rough shore or spending my strength in vain to scale the beetling crags.
Nor was that all, for crawling together on flat tables of rock or letting themselves drop into the sea with loud reports I beheld huge slimy monsters—soft snails, as it were, of incredible bigness—two or three score of them together, making the rocks to echo with their barkings.
I have understood since that they were sea lions, and entirely harmless. But the look of them, added to the difficulty of the shore and the high running of the surf, was more than enough to disgust me of that landing-place. I felt willing rather to starve at sea than to confront such perils.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction:
It was broad day when I awoke and found myself tossing at the south-west end of Treasure Island. The great mass of Spy-glass mountain loomed above me, its dark bulk rising sheer from the sea. To the left, I could see Haulbowline Head, a jagged promontory with cliffs that fell abruptly into the roaring breakers below. Mizzenmast Hill stood to the right, its slopes dotted with fallen rocks and boulders, over which the surf thundered relentlessly.

At first, I thought to paddle ashore, but the perilous nature of the coast quickly dissuaded me. The waves broke with such force against the rocks that any attempt to land would be madness. The cliffs were too steep to climb, and the surf too strong to risk being dashed against the stones. As I scanned the shoreline, I noticed numerous large, dark shapes sprawled upon the rocks and bobbing in the water. They emitted loud barking noises that echoed across the cove, and their slimy, monstrous forms filled me with dread.

Only later did I learn these creatures were harmless sea lions, but at that moment, their appearance, combined with the treacherous coast and the relentless surf, convinced me that landing there was impossible. Better to face starvation at sea than to risk being dashed to pieces or attacked by these so-called monsters.

simple_agent_extraction_refined_1.text:
It was broad day when I awoke and found myself tossing at the south-west end of Treasure Island. The sun was just rising, but a thick bank of mist hung low over the sea, hiding the horizon and dimming the light. Close at hand, I could see the great bulk of Spy-glass mountain, its dark mass rising sheer from the water. To the left lay Haulbowline Head, a high, precipitous cliff, and to the right Mizzenmast Hill, with its steep slopes and the great masses of fallen rock that lay scattered at its base. Between these points the shore was broken and dangerous, with the sea breaking in heavy rollers that sent up clouds of spray and thundered upon the rocks.

I was not more than a quarter of a mile from the shore, and at first I thought to paddle in and land. But the breakers were so strong and the rocks so numerous that the attempt was madness. The cliffs rose sheer and smooth, too high and too steep to climb, and the surf dashed and foamed among the fallen stones with a noise like thunder. As I looked, I saw many large, dark creatures crawling on the flat rocks and slipping into the sea with loud reports, barking and grunting as they went. They were slimy and monstrous in appearance, and their cries were harsh and strange.

I shuddered at the sight and the sound, and the thought of being dashed against those rocks or of trying to scale the cliffs was more than I could bear. Though I was hungry and faint, I resolved to keep away from that shore, preferring to starve at sea rather than risk such a landing. Only afterward did I learn that these creatures were harmless sea lions, but at that moment they seemed to me like slimy monsters guarding a dreadful coast.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing: The sun was just rising, casting a golden glow over the dense jungle that covered the island. I could hear the distant cries of seabirds and the gentle lapping of waves against the shore. My head ached, and my body felt weak from the ordeal, but I was alive. Slowly, I sat up and looked around, trying to piece together what had happened. The wreckage of the ship was scattered along the beach, and I could see the remnants of the sloop that had brought us here. I remembered the mutiny, the fight for the treasure, and the narrow escape from the pirates. As I stood, I noticed footprints leading inland, and I knew I had to follow them to find the others and the treasure. The island was both beautiful and dangerous, with thick undergrowth and the promise of hidden secrets. I steeled myself for the challenges ahead, determined to survive and claim the treasure that had brought us all here. The adventure was far from over, and every step I took was a step deeper into the mystery of Treasure Island.

events.title: A New Plan for Landfall and the Coracle's Treacherous Nature
detailed_summary: The narrator spots a more promising landing area north of Haulbowline Head: a stretch of yellow sand leading to Cape of the Woods, which is covered in tall pines.
He remembers Silver's information about a northward current along the west coast and, seeing he is already in its grip, decides to aim for Cape of the Woods.
The sea is relatively calm with a gentle south wind, allowing his light coracle to ride the swells surprisingly well.
He often lies low, peeking over the gunwale, watching large waves pass without upsetting the boat, which dances lightly over them.
Feeling bolder, he tries to paddle, but the slightest shift in weight causes the coracle to behave erratically, nosediving steeply into a wave and drenching him.
Terrified, he returns to his prone position, and the coracle resumes its gentle movement, making it clear that it resists being actively steered and casting doubt on his ability to reach land.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: In the meantime I had a better chance, as I supposed, before me.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: It was plain she was not to be interfered with, and at that rate, since I could in no way influence her course, what hope had I left of reaching land?

events.text_segment:
In the meantime I had a better chance, as I supposed, before me. North of Haulbowline Head, the land runs in a long way, leaving at low tide a long stretch of yellow sand. To the north of that, again, there comes another cape—Cape of the Woods, as it was marked upon the chart—buried in tall green pines, which descended to the margin of the sea.
I remembered what Silver had said about the current that sets northward along the whole west coast of Treasure Island, and seeing from my position that I was already under its influence, I preferred to leave Haulbowline Head behind me and reserve my strength for an attempt to land upon the kindlier-looking Cape of the Woods.
There was a great, smooth swell upon the sea. The wind blowing steady and gentle from the south, there was no contrariety between that and the current, and the billows rose and fell unbroken.
Had it been otherwise, I must long ago have perished; but as it was, it is surprising how easily and securely my little and light boat could ride. Often, as I still lay at the bottom and kept no more than an eye above the gunwale, I would see a big blue summit heaving close above me; yet the coracle would but bounce a little, dance as if on springs, and subside on the other side into the trough as lightly as a bird.
I began after a little to grow very bold and sat up to try my skill at paddling. But even a small change in the disposition of the weight will produce violent changes in the behaviour of a coracle. And I had hardly moved before the boat, giving up at once her gentle dancing movement, ran straight down a slope of water so steep that it made me giddy, and struck her nose, with a spout of spray, deep into the side of the next wave.
I was drenched and terrified, and fell instantly back into my old position, whereupon the coracle seemed to find her head again and led me as softly as before among the billows. It was plain she was not to be interfered with, and at that rate, since I could in no way influence her course, what hope had I left of reaching land?

The sea was comparatively calm, and a gentle south wind was blowing, so that my light coracle rode the swells surprisingly well. I lay low, peering over the gunwale, watching the great waves pass without upsetting the boat, which danced lightly over them. Feeling bolder, I tried to paddle, but the slightest shift in my weight caused the coracle to behave erratically, nosediving steeply into a wave and drenching me. Terrified, I returned to my prone position, and the coracle resumed its gentle movement, making it clear that it resisted being actively steered and casting doubt on my ability to reach land.

simple_agent_extraction_refined_1.text: In the meantime I had a better chance, as I supposed, before me. To the north of Haulbowline Head there was a long stretch of yellow sand, which ran out into the sea, and beyond it the land rose again in a low headland, covered with tall pines, called the Cape of the Woods. The sand seemed to run out into the sea, and the headland beyond it was the first land I had seen for many a mile. I remembered Silver's information about the current running northward along the west coast, and seeing that I was already in its grip, I resolved to make for the Cape of the Woods, reserving my strength for the effort. The sea was not calm, but the wind was light and from the south, and the swell rolled in long, smooth waves. My little coracle rode these swells surprisingly well, rising and falling with them, and I found myself lying low, peering over the gunwale, watching the great waves pass beneath me without upsetting the boat, which danced lightly over them. Time after time I lay thus, watching the water, the foam, and the sunlight, and the coracle seemed to glide as if it had a life of its own. At length, feeling bolder, I tried to paddle, but the slightest shift in my weight caused the coracle to behave erratically; it nosedived steeply into a wave, and I was drenched with the cold spray. Terrified, I lay down again, and the coracle resumed its gentle movement, as if it refused to be steered by me. I was left to drift, uncertain whether I should ever reach the land I longed for.

simple_agent_extraction_refined_2.text: In the meantime I had a better chance, as I supposed, before me. To the north of Haulbowline Head the land ran out in a long way at low tide, and there was a stretch of yellow sand, which led to the Cape of the Woods, a low headland covered with tall pines that descended to the margin of the sea. I remembered Silver's information about the current running northward along the west coast, and seeing that I was already in its grip, I resolved to make for the Cape of the Woods. The wind was light and from the south, and there was no conflict between wind and current; the sea was smooth and the swell rolled in long, gentle waves. My little coracle rode these swells surprisingly well. I lay low at the bottom of the boat, with only one eye above the gunwale, watching the great waves pass beneath me without upsetting the boat, which bounced and danced lightly over them, then subsided like a bird settling on the water. Feeling bolder, I tried to paddle, but the slightest shift in my weight caused the coracle to behave erratically; it nosedived steeply into a wave, and I was drenched with cold spray. Terrified, I lay down again, and the coracle resumed its gentle movement, as if it refused to be steered by me. I could not influence its course, and I was left to drift, doubting whether I should ever reach the land I longed for.

In the meantime I had a better chance, as I supposed, before me. The ship was now in full sail, and the wind was fair; the sun was shining, and the sea was smooth. I stood on the deck, looking out over the blue water, my heart beating with a strange mixture of excitement and fear. The adventure that lay ahead was unknown, but I felt a thrill at the thought of it.

Jim Hawkins, the young hero of our tale, had already begun to understand the gravity of the situation. The treasure map, with its cryptic marks and mysterious clues, was the key to a fortune beyond imagining. Yet, it was also a beacon that would draw all manner of danger and treachery.

As the days passed, the crew settled into their routine, but the tension was palpable. Captain Smollett, a man of stern discipline and clear judgment, kept a watchful eye on the men. Long John Silver, the ship's cook, was a figure of both charm and menace, his one-legged gait and parrot companion making him a memorable character.

The voyage was not without its perils. Storms threatened to dash the ship against the rocks, and the threat of mutiny lurked beneath the surface. Yet, through it all, the promise of treasure kept the men focused and determined.

When we finally reached the island, the real adventure began. The dense jungle, the hidden coves, and the ancient landmarks described in the map all came to life before our eyes. The search for the treasure was fraught with danger, as rival factions vied for control and the secrets of the island revealed themselves slowly.

In the end, it was courage, loyalty, and quick thinking that saw us through. The treasure was found, but not without cost. Friends were lost, and the true value of the journey was measured not in gold, but in the bonds forged and the lessons learned.

Thus concludes the tale of Treasure Island, a story of adventure, danger, and the enduring spirit of exploration.

events.title: Learning to Steer and the Agony of Thirst
detailed_summary: Despite his fear, the narrator keeps his composure, first bailing out the coracle with his sea-cap.
He then carefully studies how the coracle naturally navigates through the waves, observing that it threads its way through the valleys and avoids the crests.
He devises a strategy: lie still to maintain balance but use the paddle occasionally in smoother water to nudge the coracle towards land.
This method is exhausting and slow, but he visibly gains ground, making some eastward progress even though he misses Cape of the Woods.
As he gets closer to the next promontory, he is tormented by extreme thirst due to the sun, saltwater spray, and the tantalizing sight of nearby trees.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: I began to be horribly frightened, but I kept my head, for all that.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: The sight of the trees so near at hand had almost made me sick with longing, but the current had soon carried me past the point, and as the next reach of sea opened out, I beheld a sight that changed the nature of my thoughts.

events.text_segment:
I began to be horribly frightened, but I kept my head, for all that. First, moving with all care, I gradually baled out the coracle with my sea-cap; then, getting my eye once more above the gunwale, I set myself to study how it was she managed to slip so quietly through the rollers.
I found each wave, instead of the big, smooth glossy mountain it looks from shore or from a vessel’s deck, was for all the world like any range of hills on dry land, full of peaks and smooth places and valleys. The coracle, left to herself, turning from side to side, threaded, so to speak, her way through these lower parts and avoided the steep slopes and higher, toppling summits of the wave.
“Well, now,” thought I to myself, “it is plain I must lie where I am and not disturb the balance; but it is plain also that I can put the paddle over the side and from time to time, in smooth places, give her a shove or two towards land.” No sooner thought upon than done. There I lay on my elbows in the most trying attitude, and every now and again gave a weak stroke or two to turn her head to shore.
It was very tiring and slow work, yet I did visibly gain ground; and as we drew near the Cape of the Woods, though I saw I must infallibly miss that point, I had still made some hundred yards of easting. I was, indeed, close in. I could see the cool green tree-tops swaying together in the breeze, and I felt sure I should make the next promontory without fail.
It was high time, for I now began to be tortured with thirst. The glow of the sun from above, its thousandfold reflection from the waves, the sea-water that fell and dried upon me, caking my very lips with salt, combined to make my throat burn and my brain ache. The sight of the trees so near at hand had almost made me sick with longing, but the current had soon carried me past the point, and as the next reach of sea opened out, I beheld a sight that changed the nature of my thoughts.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: I began to be horribly frightened, but I kept my head, for all that. I took off my sea-cap and began bailing out the coracle, which was filling fast with the spray. The water was cold and the task was exhausting, but I managed to keep the boat afloat. Then I sat still and watched how the coracle behaved in the waves. It seemed to thread its way through the valleys between the crests, avoiding the top of the waves. I realized that if I kept still, the boat would maintain its balance, but I could use the paddle occasionally in the smoother water to nudge it towards the shore. It was slow and tiring work, but I could see that I was making some progress eastward, though I missed the Cape of the Woods. As I neared the next promontory, the sun beat down mercilessly, the salt spray stung my lips, and the sight of the trees on the shore tormented me with thirst. Yet I kept on, determined to reach land.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
I began to be horribly frightened, but I kept my head, for all that. The night was dark and the wind howled through the rigging, making the ship creak and groan as if it were alive. I clutched the lantern tightly, its flickering light casting eerie shadows on the deck. Every sound seemed magnified in the stillness, and I could hear the distant splash of waves against the hull.

Suddenly, a figure emerged from the shadows—a tall man with a weather-beaten face and a patch over one eye. His voice was low and rough as he spoke, "So, Jim, you've come at last."

It was Long John Silver. My heart pounded in my chest, but I forced myself to stand firm. "What do you want?" I asked, trying to keep my voice steady.

Silver smiled, revealing a gold tooth that gleamed in the lantern light. "I want to talk, lad. There's more at stake here than you know."

He motioned for me to follow him below deck. Reluctantly, I obeyed, descending into the dimly lit cabin where the rest of the crew awaited. The air was thick with tension, and I could see the glint of cutlasses and pistols at their sides.

"Listen well," Silver began, his tone serious. "We're not just after treasure; we're after survival. The island holds dangers beyond gold and silver."

As he spoke, I realized that the adventure I had imagined was far more perilous than I had ever dreamed. Yet, despite the fear gnawing at my insides, a spark of determination ignited within me. I would see this through, no matter the cost.

The night wore on, and plans were laid. I knew that the coming days would test every ounce of courage I possessed. But with Silver's cunning and my own resolve, perhaps we stood a chance against the perils that awaited us on Treasure Island.

events.title: The Mysterious Hispaniola and Suspicions of Desertion
detailed_summary: The narrator suddenly sees the Hispaniola under sail less than half a mile away, a sight that initially leaves him unsure whether to feel glad or sorry due to his desperate thirst.
The ship is under main-sail and two jibs, initially heading north-west, but then starts veering erratically westward, making him think they've spotted him.
However, the Hispaniola repeatedly falls into the wind's eye, her sails shivering helplessly, leading the narrator to believe the crew is drunk.
The ship continues its uncontrolled movements, sailing in swoops and dashes, always ending up stalled, convincing the narrator that no one is steering.
He speculates that the crew is either incapacitated by drink or has abandoned the ship, and considers the possibility of regaining control of the vessel for Captain Smollett.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Right in front of me, not half a mile away, I beheld the Hispaniola under sail.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Either they were dead drunk or had deserted her, I thought, and perhaps if I could get on board I might return the vessel to her captain.

events.text_segment:
Right in front of me, not half a mile away, I beheld the Hispaniola under sail. I made sure, of course, that I should be taken; but I was so distressed for want of water that I scarce knew whether to be glad or sorry at the thought, and long before I had come to a conclusion, surprise had taken entire possession of my mind and I could do nothing but stare and wonder.
The Hispaniola was under her main-sail and two jibs, and the beautiful white canvas shone in the sun like snow or silver. When I first sighted her, all her sails were drawing; she was lying a course about north-west, and I presumed the men on board were going round the island on their way back to the anchorage. Presently she began to fetch more and more to the westward, so that I thought they had sighted me and were going about in chase. At last, however, she fell right into the wind’s eye, was taken dead aback, and stood there awhile helpless, with her sails shivering.
“Clumsy fellows,” said I; “they must still be drunk as owls.” And I thought how Captain Smollett would have set them skipping.
Meanwhile the schooner gradually fell off and filled again upon another tack, sailed swiftly for a minute or so, and brought up once more dead in the wind’s eye. Again and again was this repeated. To and fro, up and down, north, south, east, and west, the Hispaniola sailed by swoops and dashes, and at each repetition ended as she had begun, with idly flapping canvas. It became plain to me that nobody was steering. And if so, where were the men? Either they were dead drunk or had deserted her, I thought, and perhaps if I could get on board I might return the vessel to her captain.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: Right in front of me, not half a mile away, I beheld the Hispaniola under sail. At first I was not sure whether to be glad or sorry. Glad, because the sight of the ship meant rescue; sorry, because my throat was parched with thirst, and I feared I might not live to reach her. The ship was under main-sail and two jibs, and was heading north-west, but presently she began to veer erratically westward. I thought at first that they had seen me, and were making for the island. But then the Hispaniola fell into the eye of the wind, and her sails shivered helplessly. She was caught in the wind’s dead spot, and no one seemed to be steering. The ship sailed in swoops and dashes, always ending up stalled, and I was convinced that the crew was either drunk or had abandoned her. I thought of Captain Smollett, and the possibility of regaining control of the vessel for him.

events.title: The Audacious Chase and Perilous Pursuit
detailed_summary: The narrator observes that both his coracle and the Hispaniola are being carried southward by the current at the same speed.
He believes he can catch the erratically sailing schooner if he dares to sit up and paddle, motivated by adventure and the thought of fresh water on board.
He bravely sits up, gets sprayed by a wave, but persists in paddling with strength and caution.
He encounters a heavy sea that forces him to stop and bail, his heart pounding, but he gradually gets the hang of managing the coracle in pursuit.
He gains rapidly on the Hispaniola, seeing the tiller banging about and no sign of anyone on deck, reinforcing his belief that the ship is deserted or the crew incapacitated below.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: The current was bearing coracle and schooner southward at an equal rate.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: If not, the men were lying drunk below, where I might batten them down, perhaps, and do what I chose with the ship.

events.text_segment:
The current was bearing coracle and schooner southward at an equal rate. As for the latter’s sailing, it was so wild and intermittent, and she hung each time so long in irons, that she certainly gained nothing, if she did not even lose. If only I dared to sit up and paddle, I made sure that I could overhaul her. The scheme had an air of adventure that inspired me, and the thought of the water breaker beside the fore companion doubled my growing courage.
Up I got, was welcomed almost instantly by another cloud of spray, but this time stuck to my purpose and set myself, with all my strength and caution, to paddle after the unsteered Hispaniola. Once I shipped a sea so heavy that I had to stop and bail, with my heart fluttering like a bird, but gradually I got into the way of the thing and guided my coracle among the waves, with only now and then a blow upon her bows and a dash of foam in my face.
I was now gaining rapidly on the schooner; I could see the brass glisten on the tiller as it banged about, and still no soul appeared upon her decks. I could not choose but suppose she was deserted. If not, the men were lying drunk below, where I might batten them down, perhaps, and do what I chose with the ship.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: The current was bearing coracle and schooner southward at an equal rate. I could see the Hispaniola's sails flapping idly, her course erratic and uncertain. A sudden impulse seized me; if I dared to sit up and paddle, I might catch her. The thought of fresh water on board, and the adventure of the chase, spurred me on. I braced myself, sat up, and took my paddle in hand. A wave broke over me, drenching me to the skin, but I held firm. With strength and caution, I began to paddle, feeling the coracle respond beneath me. A heavy sea rolled in, forcing me to stop and bail, my heart pounding with the effort and excitement. Gradually, I found my rhythm, managing the coracle with growing skill. I gained rapidly on the Hispaniola, watching the tiller bang about wildly, and noting with a chill that there was no sign of life on deck. It seemed the ship was deserted, or that the crew lay incapacitated below.

A sudden impulse seized me; if I dared to sit up and paddle, I might catch her. The thought of fresh water on board, and the adventure of the chase, spurred me on. I braced myself, sat up, and took my paddle in hand. A wave broke over me, drenching me to the skin, but I held firm. With strength and caution, I began to paddle, feeling the coracle respond beneath me. A heavy sea rolled in, forcing me to stop and bail, my heart pounding with the effort and excitement. Gradually, I found my rhythm, managing the coracle with growing skill. I gained rapidly on the Hispaniola, watching the tiller bang about wildly, and noting with a chill that there was no sign of life on deck. It seemed the ship was deserted, or that the crew lay incapacitated below.

The thought of the water breaker on board, and the fresh water it contained, was a strong inducement. The adventure of the thing, too, was not without its charm. The current was bearing coracle and schooner southward at an equal rate. The sun was sinking low, casting a golden hue over the restless sea, and the sails of the schooner flapped gently in the evening breeze. Jim Hawkins stood at the prow, his eyes fixed on the distant horizon where the outline of Treasure Island loomed like a dark shadow against the fading light. The air was thick with anticipation and the promise of adventure, for within the island's hidden coves lay the legendary treasure that had drawn so many to these perilous waters.

Long John Silver, with his one good leg planted firmly on the deck, surveyed the scene with a calculating gaze. His parrot squawked loudly, breaking the silence that had settled over the crew. The men whispered among themselves, their voices tinged with both excitement and fear, aware that the journey ahead would test their courage and resolve.

As the schooner edged closer to the island, the dense jungle canopy became visible, concealing secrets and dangers alike. The map, carefully guarded by Jim, was the key to unlocking the treasure's location, but it was also a source of contention and mistrust among the crew. The night was falling fast, and with it came the realization that the true adventure was only just beginning.

events.title: Closing In and the Desperate Leap Aboard
detailed_summary: The Hispaniola's tendency to stand still, heading south and yawing, while unhelpful for her own progress, makes it difficult for the narrator to catch her as she still drifts away with the current and leeway.
A temporary drop in the breeze gives him an opportunity as the Hispaniola slowly revolves, presenting her stern, with a cabin window open and a lamp still burning.
He redoubles his efforts and begins to overhaul the ship again.
Just as he is about a hundred yards away, the wind returns, and the Hispaniola fills her sails and speeds off.
Initial despair turns to joy as the ship unexpectedly turns broadside and then rapidly closes the distance towards him.

He suddenly realizes the danger as the schooner bears down on him; with no time to think, he springs to his feet as the bowsprit passes over him, leaps, and catches the jib-boom, his coracle being crushed beneath the Hispaniola. He is left clinging to the ship, his retreat cut off.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: For some time she had been doing the worse thing possible for me—standing still.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: With one hand I caught the jib-boom, while my foot was lodged between the stay and the brace; and as I still clung there panting, a dull blow told me that the schooner had charged down upon and struck the coracle and that I was left without retreat on the Hispaniola.

events.text_segment:
For some time she had been doing the worse thing possible for me—standing still. She headed nearly due south, yawing, of course, all the time. Each time she fell off, her sails partly filled, and these brought her in a moment right to the wind again. I have said this was the worst thing possible for me, for helpless as she looked in this situation, with the canvas cracking like cannon and the blocks trundling and banging on the deck, she still continued to run away from me, not only with the speed of the current, but by the whole amount of her leeway, which was naturally great.
But now, at last, I had my chance. The breeze fell for some seconds, very low, and the current gradually turning her, the Hispaniola revolved slowly round her centre and at last presented me her stern, with the cabin window still gaping open and the lamp over the table still burning on into the day. The main-sail hung drooped like a banner. She was stock-still but for the current.
For the last little while I had even lost, but now redoubling my efforts, I began once more to overhaul the chase.
I was not a hundred yards from her when the wind came again in a clap; she filled on the port tack and was off again, stooping and skimming like a swallow.
My first impulse was one of despair, but my second was towards joy. Round she came, till she was broadside on to me—round still till she had covered a half and then two thirds and then three quarters of the distance that separated us. I could see the waves boiling white under her forefoot. Immensely tall she looked to me from my low station in the coracle.
And then, of a sudden, I began to comprehend. I had scarce time to think—scarce time to act and save myself. I was on the summit of one swell when the schooner came stooping over the next. The bowsprit was over my head. I sprang to my feet and leaped, stamping the coracle under water. With one hand I caught the jib-boom, while my foot was lodged between the stay and the brace; and as I still clung there panting, a dull blow told me that the schooner had charged down upon and struck the coracle and that I was left without retreat on the Hispaniola.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
For some time she had been doing the worse thing possible for me—standing still. The silence between us grew heavier with each passing moment, thickening the air until it was almost suffocating. I could feel the weight of her gaze, steady and unyielding, as if she were trying to read the very thoughts that churned within me. It was a look that held both accusation and sorrow, a silent reproach that cut deeper than any words could.

I shifted uneasily, my fingers twitching at my sides, desperate to break the tension but unsure how. The room around us seemed to shrink, the walls closing in as the unspoken words piled up like stones between us. I wanted to speak, to explain, to bridge the gulf that had opened, but the right words eluded me, slipping away like smoke through my grasp.

Her stillness was a mirror reflecting my own turmoil, a reminder of the distance that had grown between us. It was as if time itself had paused, holding its breath in anticipation of what might come next. I could almost hear the ticking of an unseen clock, each second stretching into an eternity.

Finally, she took a step forward, breaking the spell. Her voice was soft, trembling with emotion, "Why did you keep this from me?"

The question hung in the air, heavy and unavoidable. I swallowed hard, the lump in my throat making it difficult to speak. "I was afraid," I admitted, the words barely above a whisper. "Afraid of losing you, of what you might think."

She nodded slowly, her eyes glistening with unshed tears. "We can't move forward if we don't face the truth," she said gently. "Standing still only keeps us trapped in the past."

Her words resonated within me, stirring a resolve I hadn't felt in days. I reached out, taking her hand in mine, feeling the warmth and reassurance it offered. Together, we would find a way through the silence, step by step, toward a future where we could stand side by side once more.

events.title: Grim Discovery on the Hispaniola
detailed_summary: The narrator, Jim Hawkins, narrowly avoids being thrown overboard as he boards the erratically moving Hispaniola.
He finds the deck deserted, bearing signs of the recent mutiny, including filth and an empty bottle.
A sudden lurch of the ship reveals two figures on the after-deck: the mutineers left as watchmen.
One, known by his red cap, lies dead and stiff, his arms outstretched and teeth bared in a fixed grin.
The other, Israel Hands, is propped against the bulwarks, appearing extremely pale and weak.
As the ship continues to toss violently, the dead man's body slides around without his expression changing.
Israel Hands seems to slump further with each movement, his face gradually becoming hidden from Jim's view.
Jim notices dark bloodstains on the planks around both men, leading him to conclude they had fought and killed each other in a drunken conflict.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: I had scarce gained a position on the bowsprit when the flying jib flapped and filled upon the other tack, with a report like a gun.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: At the same time, I observed, around both of them, splashes of dark blood upon the planks and began to feel sure that they had killed each other in their drunken wrath.

events.text_segment:
I had scarce gained a position on the bowsprit when the flying jib flapped and filled upon the other tack, with a report like a gun. The schooner trembled to her keel under the reverse, but next moment, the other sails still drawing, the jib flapped back again and hung idle.
This had nearly tossed me off into the sea; and now I lost no time, crawled back along the bowsprit, and tumbled head foremost on the deck.
I was on the lee side of the forecastle, and the mainsail, which was still drawing, concealed from me a certain portion of the after-deck. Not a soul was to be seen. The planks, which had not been swabbed since the mutiny, bore the print of many feet, and an empty bottle, broken by the neck, tumbled to and fro like a live thing in the scuppers.
Suddenly the Hispaniola came right into the wind. The jibs behind me cracked aloud, the rudder slammed to, the whole ship gave a sickening heave and shudder, and at the same moment the main-boom swung inboard, the sheet groaning in the blocks, and showed me the lee after-deck.
There were the two watchmen, sure enough: red-cap on his back, as stiff as a handspike, with his arms stretched out like those of a crucifix and his teeth showing through his open lips; Israel Hands propped against the bulwarks, his chin on his chest, his hands lying open before him on the deck, his face as white, under its tan, as a tallow candle.
For a while the ship kept bucking and sidling like a vicious horse, the sails filling, now on one tack, now on another, and the boom swinging to and fro till the mast groaned aloud under the strain. Now and again too there would come a cloud of light sprays over the bulwark and a heavy blow of the ship’s bows against the swell; so much heavier weather was made of it by this great rigged ship than by my home-made, lop-sided coracle, now gone to the bottom of the sea.
At every jump of the schooner, red-cap slipped to and fro, but—what was ghastly to behold—neither his attitude nor his fixed teeth-disclosing grin was anyway disturbed by this rough usage. At every jump too, Hands appeared still more to sink into himself and settle down upon the deck, his feet sliding ever the farther out, and the whole body canting towards the stern, so that his face became, little by little, hid from me; and at last I could see nothing beyond his ear and the frayed ringlet of one whisker.
At the same time, I observed, around both of them, splashes of dark blood upon the planks and began to feel sure that they had killed each other in their drunken wrath.

The ship lurched and heeled over, and I was thrown forward, but I caught hold of the rigging. The deck was deserted, but the signs of the mutiny were everywhere: the filth and disorder, the empty bottle rolling about, and the general air of neglect. Suddenly, as the ship rolled again, I saw two figures on the after-deck. One was a man with a red cap, lying stiff and dead, his arms outstretched and his teeth bared in a fixed grin. The other was Israel Hands, propped against the bulwarks, pale and weak, his face gradually hidden as he slumped further with each movement of the ship. Dark bloodstains marked the planks around them both, and I realized they had fought and killed each other in a drunken quarrel.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
I had scarce gained a position on the bowsprit when the flying jib flapped and filled upon the other tack, with a report like a gun. The ship heeled over, and the spray dashed in my face; the wind roared in the rigging, and the sails strained and quivered as if they would tear themselves to pieces. I clung to the ropes, my heart beating fast, for I was young and inexperienced, and the sea was a wild and terrible thing.

The captain stood at the helm, his eyes fixed on the horizon, where the black shape of the Hispaniola loomed through the mist. "Steady, men!" he cried. "We'll have her yet!"

The crew scrambled to their stations, shouting orders and hauling on the sheets. The ship answered to the helm, and the sails filled with the freshening breeze. The chase was on.

I looked over the side and saw the waves tumbling and breaking, white with foam. The salt spray stung my eyes, and the wind tore at my clothes. But I felt a thrill of excitement; this was adventure, the very stuff of stories.

Suddenly, a shout rang out from the lookout in the crow's nest. "Sail ho!"

The captain nodded grimly. "There she is, the treasure ship. Full sail, men!"

The Hispaniola surged forward, her timbers creaking and groaning under the strain. The chase was close now, the two ships almost side by side. The men prepared to board, weapons ready, faces set with determination.

I gripped the ropes tighter, my knuckles white. The air was thick with the smell of salt and gunpowder. The battle was about to begin.

As the ships drew alongside, the pirates shouted their battle cries, and the clash of steel rang out. The deck was a chaos of men fighting for their lives, the air filled with smoke and the roar of cannon.

Amidst the turmoil, I caught sight of Long John Silver, his one leg braced firmly, a cruel smile on his face. He was a man to be feared, cunning and ruthless.

The fight raged on, but at last, the pirates were driven back, and the Hispaniola was ours. The treasure was safe.

Exhausted but triumphant, we set sail for home, the sun rising over the horizon, promising a new day and new adventures to come.

events.title: A Wounded Mutineer's Plea
detailed_summary: During a brief calm, Israel Hands stirs, moaning and shifting, revealing he is still alive.
The sound of Hands's pain and weakness initially evokes sympathy in Jim.
However, Jim's pity vanishes when he recalls Hands's role in the mutiny, which he overheard from the apple barrel.
Jim approaches Hands and addresses him with irony.
Hands, too weak to show surprise or respond at length, simply requests “Brandy.”

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: While I was thus looking and wondering, in a calm moment, when the ship was still, Israel Hands turned partly round and with a low moan writhed himself back to the position in which I had seen him first.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: All he could do was to utter one word, “Brandy.”

events.text_segment:
While I was thus looking and wondering, in a calm moment, when the ship was still, Israel Hands turned partly round and with a low moan writhed himself back to the position in which I had seen him first. The moan, which told of pain and deadly weakness, and the way in which his jaw hung open went right to my heart. But when I remembered the talk I had overheard from the apple barrel, all pity left me.
I walked aft until I reached the main-mast.
“Come aboard, Mr. Hands,” I said ironically.
He rolled his eyes round heavily, but he was too far gone to express surprise. All he could do was to utter one word, “Brandy.”

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: While I was thus looking and wondering, in a calm moment, when the ship was still, Israel Hands turned partly round and with a low moan writhed himself back to the position in which I had seen him first. The sound of his pain and weakness touched me at first, and I was sorry for him; but the remembrance of his treachery, which I had overheard from the apple barrel, came back to me, and I looked at him with a different eye. "So, Hands," said I, "you are not dead yet?" He opened his eyes and looked at me, but was too weak to speak. "Brandy," he whispered.

The night deepened, and the stars began to twinkle overhead, casting a faint glow upon the restless sea. In that moment, the vastness of the ocean seemed to swallow all our troubles.

events.title: Foraging Amidst Cabin Chaos
detailed_summary: Recognizing the need for haste, Jim carefully navigates the unstable deck to reach the ship's cabin.
He discovers the cabin in a state of utter confusion, with locked compartments broken into, presumably in search of the chart.
The floor is caked with mud from the mutineers' boots, the white bulkheads are smeared with dirty handprints, and empty bottles clink in the corners.
A medical book belonging to the doctor lies open and damaged, its pages likely torn out for lighting pipes.
Jim proceeds to the cellar, finding all the barrels gone and a surprising number of bottles emptied and discarded, indicating constant drunkenness among the mutineers.
He successfully locates a bottle containing some brandy for Hands.
For himself, he gathers biscuits, pickled fruits, raisins, and a piece of cheese.
Returning to the deck, Jim secures his own supplies, takes a drink of water, and only then gives the brandy to Hands.

segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: With these I came on deck, put down my own stock behind the rudder head and well out of the coxswain’s reach, went forward to the water-breaker, and had a good deep drink of water, and then, and not till then, gave Hands the brandy.

events.text_segment:
It occurred to me there was no time to lose, and dodging the boom as it once more lurched across the deck, I slipped aft and down the companion stairs into the cabin.
It was such a scene of confusion as you can hardly fancy. All the lockfast places had been broken open in quest of the chart. The floor was thick with mud where ruffians had sat down to drink or consult after wading in the marshes round their camp. The bulkheads, all painted in clear white and beaded round with gilt, bore a pattern of dirty hands. Dozens of empty bottles clinked together in corners to the rolling of the ship. One of the doctor’s medical books lay open on the table, half of the leaves gutted out, I suppose, for pipelights. In the midst of all this the lamp still cast a smoky glow, obscure and brown as umber.
I went into the cellar; all the barrels were gone, and of the bottles a most surprising number had been drunk out and thrown away. Certainly, since the mutiny began, not a man of them could ever have been sober.
Foraging about, I found a bottle with some brandy left, for Hands; and for myself I routed out some biscuit, some pickled fruits, a great bunch of raisins, and a piece of cheese. With these I came on deck, put down my own stock behind the rudder head and well out of the coxswain’s reach, went forward to the water-breaker, and had a good deep drink of water, and then, and not till then, gave Hands the brandy.

Returning to the deck, I secured my own provisions, took a long drink of water, and only then gave the brandy to Hands.
